lines.value: uart atawa universal asynchronous receiver transmitter nyaeta bagean hardware komputer nu narjamahkeun antara bit bit paralel data jeung bit bit serial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: uart biasana mangrupa ic nu digunakeun keur komunikasi serial dina komputer atawa port serial parangkat periperal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: uart kiwari diasupkeun kana sababaraha mikrokontroler contona pic16f628
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bits have to be moved from one place to another using wires or some other medium
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: over many miles the expense of the wires becomes large
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to reduce the expense of long communication links carrying several bits in parallel data bits are sent sequentially one after another using a uart to convert the transmitted bits between sequential and parallel form at each end of the link
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each uart contains a shift register which is the fundamental method of conversion between serial and parallel forms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by convention teletype style uarts send a start bit five to eight data bits least significant bit first an optional parity bit and then a stop bit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the start bit is the opposite polarity of the data line's normal state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the stop bit is the data line's normal state and provides a space before the next character can start
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is called asynchronous start stop transmission
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in mechanical teletypes the stop bit was often stretched to two bit times to give the mechanism more time to finish printing a character
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a stretched stop bit also helps resynchronization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the parity bit can either make the number of bits odd or even or it can be omitted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: odd parity is more reliable because it assures that there will always be a data transition and this permits many uarts to resynchronize
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: speeds for uarts are in bits per second bit s or bps although often incorrectly called the baud rate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: standard mechanical teletype rates are 45.5 110 and 150 bit s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers have used from 110 to 230400 bit s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the uart usually does not directly generate or receive the voltage levels that are put onto the wires interconnecting different equipment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an interface standard is used which defines voltage levels and other characteristics of the interconnection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: examples of interface standards are eia rs 232 rs 422 and rs 485
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: depending on the limits of the communication channel to which the uart is ultimately connected communication may be full duplex both send and receive at the same time or half duplex devices take turns transmitting and receiving
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beside traditional wires the uart is used for communication over other serial channels such as an optical fiber infrared wireless bluetooth in its serial port profile spp and the dc lin for power line communication
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today 2006 uart is commonly used with rs232 for embedded systems communications
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is useful to communicate between microcontrollers and also with pcs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many chips provide uart functionality in silicon and low cost chips exist to convert uart to rs232 signals for example maxim max232
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chip uart biasana diwangun ku
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an overrun error occurs when the uart cannot process the byte that just came in before the next one arrives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various uart devices have differing amounts of buffer space to hold received characters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cpu must service the uart in order to remove characters from the buffer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the cpu does not service the uart and the buffer becomes full overrun error will occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a framing error occurs when the designated start and stop bits are not valid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the start bit is used to identify the beginning of an incoming character it acts as a reference for the remaining bits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the data line is not in its normal state when the stop bit is expected a framing error will occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a parity error occurs when the number of active bits does not agree with the specified parity configuration of the uart producing a parity error
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because the parity bit is optional this error will not occur if parity has been disabled
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a break error occurs when the connection is broken
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is detected when the transmission line does not send the stop bit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word asynchronous indicates that uarts recover character timing information from the data stream using designated start and stop bits to indicate the framing of each character
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in synchronous transmission the clock data is recovered separately from the data stream and no start stop bits are used
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this improves the efficiency of transmission on suitable channels more of the bits sent are data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an asynchronous transmission sends nothing over the interconnection when the transmitting device has nothing to send but a synchronous interface must send pad characters to maintain synchronism between the receiver and transmitter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the usual filler is the ascii syn character
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this may be done automatically by the transmitting device
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some chips have both synchronous and asynchronous modes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are called usarts for universal synchronous asynchronous receivertransmitters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first uart like devices were rotating mechanical commutators
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these sent 5-bit baudot codes for mechanical teletypewriters and replaced morse code
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later ascii required a seven bit code
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when ibm rationalized computers in the early 1960s with 8-bit characters it became customary to store the ascii code in 8 bits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gordon bell designed the first uart for the pdp 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example of an early 1980s uart was the national semiconductor 8250
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1990s newer uarts were developed with on chip buffers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this allowed higher transmission speed without data loss and without requiring such frequent attention from the computer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the national semiconductor 16550 has a 16 byte fifo
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: variants include the 16c550 16c650 16c750 and 16c850
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: depending on the manufacturer different terms are used to identify devices that perform the uart functions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: intel called their 8251 device a programmable communication interface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term serial communications interface sci was first used at motorola around 1975 to refer to their start stop asynchronous serial interface device which others were calling a uart
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the less common 5 6 and 7 bit codes are now sometimes simulated with 8-bit uarts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the unused high order bits are set to 1 the value of the stop bit and idle line
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this technique cannot send or receive at full speed but provides some level of compatibility for older equipment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some very low cost home computers or embedded systems dispensed with a uart and used the cpu to sample the state of an input port or directly manipulate an output port for data transmission
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while very cpu intensive since the cpu timing was critical these schemes avoided the purchase of a costly uart chip
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the technique was known as a bit banging serial port
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: alternate uses see data disambiguation datum nyaeta statement nu ditarima dina face value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: data bentuk loba tina datum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hal nu penting dina kelas nu gede nyaeta ukuran atawa panalungtikan tina variabel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hal ieu saperti wilangan kecap atawa gambar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word data is the plural of latin datum neuter past participle of dare to give hence something given
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the past participle of to give has been used for millennia in the sense of a statement accepted at face value one of the works of euclid circa 300 bc was the dedomena in latin data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in discussions of problems in geometry mathematics engineering and so on the terms givens and data are used interchangeably
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such usage is the origin of data as a concept in computer science data are numbers words images etc accepted as they stand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in english the word datum is still used in the general sense of something given and more specifically in cartography geography and geology to mean a reference point reference line or reference surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the latin plural data is also used as a plural in english but it is also commonly treated as a mass noun and used in the singular
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example this is all the data from the experiment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this usage is inconsistent with the rules of latin grammar which would suggest these are the data ", each measurement or result being a single datum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however given the variety and irregularity of english plural constructions there seem to be no grounds for arguing that data is incorrect as a singular mass noun in english
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: raw data are numbers characters images or other outputs from devices to convert physical quantities into symbols in a very broad sense
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such data are typically further processed by a human or input into a computer stored and processed there or transmitted output to another human or computer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: raw data is a relative term data processing commonly occurs by stages and the processed data from one stage may be considered the raw data of the next
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mechanical computing devices are classified according to the means by which they represent data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an analog computer represents a datum as a voltage distance position or other physical quantity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a digital computer represents a datum as a sequence of symbols drawn from a fixed alphabet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most common digital computers use a binary alphabet that is an alphabet of two characters typically denoted 0 and 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more familiar representations such as numbers and letters are then constructed from the binary alphabet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some special forms of data are distinguished
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a computer program is a collection of data which can be interpreted as instructions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most computer languages make a distinction between programs and the other data on which programs operate but in some languages notably lisp and similar languages programs are essentially indistinguishable from other data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also useful to distinguish metadata that is a description of other data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the prototypical example of metadata is the library catalog which is a description of the contents of books
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: data on its own has no meaning only when interpreted by some kind of data processing system does it take on meaning and become information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: people or computers can find patterns in data to perceive information and information can be used to enhance knowledge
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since knowledge is prerequisite to wisdom we always want more data and information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but as modern societies verge on information overload we especially need better ways to find patterns
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: panggunaan statistik keur psikologi

lines.value: matematik terapan mangrupa cabang matematik that concerns itself with the application of mathematical knowledge to other domains

lines.value: such applications include analisis numeris mathematics of engineering linear programming optimization and operations research continuous modelling mathematical biology and bioinformatics information theory game theory probability and statistics financial mathematics actuarial science cryptography and hence combinatorics and even finite geometry to some extent graph theory as applied to network analysis and a great deal of what is called computer science

lines.value: the question of what is applied mathematics does not answer to logical classification so much as to the sociology of professionals who use math

lines.value: ladislaus josephovich bortkiewicz 7 agustus 1868 15 juli 1931 nyaeta salah saurang russian economist jeung statistician katurunan polish
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bortkiewicz lahir st petersburg imperial russia ayeuna russia sarta tamat sarjana hukum dina taun 1890
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taun 1898 manehna ngaluarkeun buku ngeunaan poisson distribution judulna the law of small numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this book he first noted that events with low frequency in a large population follow a poisson distribution even when the probabilities of the events varied
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was that book that made the prussian cavalry horse kick data famous
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the data give the number of soldiers killed by being kicked by a horse each year in each of 14 cavalry corps over a 20-year period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bortkiewicz showed that those numbers follow a poisson distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the book also examined data on child suicides
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some historians of mathematics have argued that the poisson distribution should have been named the bortkiewicz distribution in political economy bortkiewicz is important for his analysis of marx's reproduction schema in the last two volumes of capital
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bortkiewicz identified a transformation problem in marx's work which if proven would profoundly undermine marx's claim to have provided a consistent account of capitalist economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this work provided the basis of major elaborations by joseph schumpeter and paul sweezy among others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bortkiewicz died in berlin germany
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first mention of nanotechnology not yet using that name occurred in a talk given by richard feynman in 1959 entitled there's plenty of room at the bottom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: feynman suggested a means to develop the ability to manipulate atoms and molecules directly by developing a set of one tenth scale machine tools analogous to those found in any machine shop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these small tools would then help to develop and operate a next generation of one hundredth scale machine tools and so forth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the sizes get smaller we would have to redesign some tools because the relative strength of various forces would change
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gravity would become less important surface tension would become more important van der waals attraction would become important etc feynman mentioned these scaling issues during his talk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nobody has yet effectively refuted the feasibility of his proposal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term nano technology was created by tokyo science university professor norio taniguchi in 1974 to describe the precision manufacture of materials with nanometer tolerances
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1980s the term was reinvented and its definition expanded by k eric drexler particularly in his 1986 book engines of creation the coming era of nanotechnology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he explored this subject in much greater technical depth in his mit doctoral dissertation later expanded into nanosystems molecular machinery manufacturing and computation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computational methods play a key role in the field today because nanotechnologists can use them to design and simulate a wide range of molecular systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an often cited but not scientifically tangible worst case scenario is the so called grey goo a substance into which the surface objects of the earth might be transformed by amok running self replicating nano robots
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: defenders point out that smaller objects are more susceptible to damage from radiation and heat due to greater surface area-to-volume ratios nanomachines would quickly fail when exposed to harsh climates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more realistic are criticisms that point to the potential toxicity of new classes of nanosubstances that could adversely affect the stability of cell walls or disturb the immune system when inhaled or digested

lines.value: spiders have an open circulatory system meaning they don't have true blood or veins for it to travel in
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rather their bodies are filled with haemolymph which is pumped through arteries by a heart into spaces called sinuses surrounding their organs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spiders have developed several different respiratory anatomies based either on book lungs a tracheal system or both
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some very small spiders are probably also breathing directly through their body surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: primitive mygalomorph spiders have two pairs of book lungs filled with haemolymph where openings on the ventral surface of the abdomen allows air to enter and diffuse oxygen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern araneomorph spiders primary have an anterior pair of book lungs intact and the posterior pair of breathing organs modified into tracheae where oxygen is then diffused into the haemolymph
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the tracheal system oxygen interchange is much more efficient enabling cursorial hunting hunting involving extended pursuit and other advanced characteristics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spiders usually have eight eyes in various arrangements a fact which is used to taxonomically classify different species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes one pair of eyes is better developed than the rest or there are only three pairs or no eyes at all
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several families of hunting spiders have developed good to excellent vision such as wolf spiders and jumping spiders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however most spiders that lurk on flowers webs and other fixed locations waiting for prey have very poor eyesight but possess extreme sensitivity to vibrations for hunting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some tarantula have a patch of urticating hairs on their abdomens for defense which are generally absent on modern spiders and mesothelae
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: certain other species have specialized defense tactics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the golden wheeling spider of the desert escapes tarantula wasps a species of wasp that lays its eggs in a paralyzed spider so the larvae have enough food when they hatch by flipping onto its side and cartwheeling away
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--spiders reproduce by eggs laid in silk bundles called egg sacs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spiders often use elaborate mating rituals especially in the visually advanced jumping spiders to allow the male to approach close enough to inseminate the female without triggering a predatory response
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: assuming that the approach signals are exchanged correctly the male spider must make a timely departure after mating to escape before the female's normal predatory instincts come back into operation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sperm transmission is an indirect process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when a male is ready to mate he will spin a web pad onto which the sperm is discharged
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he then dips his palps also known as palpi the small leg like appendages on the front of his cephalothorax into the sperm picking it up by capillary attraction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mature male spiders have swollen bulbs on the end of their palps for this purpose and this is a useful way to identify the sex of a spider in the field
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with his palps thus charged he then goes off in search of a female
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the act of copulation occurs when the male inserts one or both palps into the female's genital opening known as the epigyne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he transfers his sperm into the female by expanding the sinuses in his palp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: very unusual behavior is seen in spiders of the genus tidarren as the male amputates one of his palps before maturation and enters his adult life with one palp only
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the palpi constitute 20% of its body mass and since this weight greatly impedes its movement the spider detaches one of the two to gain mobility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the yemeni species tidarren argo the remaining palp is then torn off by the female
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the separated palp remains attached to the female's epigynum for about four hours and apparently continues to function independently
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the meantime the female feeds on the palpless male
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: journal of zoology 2001 254:449-459 cambridge university press )
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is often said that the male usually significantly smaller than the female down to 1% of her size for tidarren sisyphoides is likely to be killed by the female after the coupling or sometimes before intercourse has occurred
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this supposed propensity is what gave the black widow spider latrodectus mactans its name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the three species of north american black widows do not seem usually to kill the male although they may and males can sometimes live in the web of a female for a while without being harmed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the male australian redback latrodectus hasselti is killed ritually by the females after it inserts its second palpus in the female genital opening in over 60% of cases the female then eats the male
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the male latrodectus hasselti know also as the australian redback spider certainly dies during mating without the female consuming it this species represents a possible strategy of male sacrifice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the male redback while copulating somersaults and twists its abdomen directly onto the fangs of its mate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most males get consumed at this stage andrade 2003 reports 65%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: males that sacrifice themselves gain the benefit of increasing their paternity relative to males who do not get cannibalized see andrade 2003 behavioral ecology vol.14:531-538
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however despite these examples and many other similar reports the story of the sacrificial male might have become greater than the truth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mating of spiders is not invariably followed by cannibalism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rainer f foelix 1982 says the supposed aggressiveness of the female spider towards the male is largely a myth only in some exceptional cases does the male fall victim to the female
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: michael roberts 1995 says it is rare for a fit male to be eaten by the female and yet spider cannibalism does occur in some species more than in others mainly species belonging to latrodectus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however there has been speculation on why this sacrifice of male mates might occur at all
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one theory is that once the male has mated if he is unlikely to mate again then further extension of his life serves no evolutionary purpose while the sacrifice of the male may help increase egg production through increased nutrition for the female
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having more offspring would give the male an advantage of having his genes passed on over other males that were not eaten
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this would be consistent with the hypothesis roberts 1995 that old or unfit males get eaten whilst younger and fitter ones may survive to mate again
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another reason promoting male self sacrifice could be low probabilities of finding another possible mate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: males of some spider species have mortality percentage of around 80% for example l
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hasselti from andrade 2003 and other latrodectus ssp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus investing more in a mate that has already been found in order to increase paternity with that copulation would increase the probability of transferring the males genes to the next generation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an accessible discussion of such hypotheses can be found in the entertaining book by judson 2002
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--spiders have a great range of variation and lifestyle although all are predatory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while spiders are generalist predators in actuality their different methods of prey capture often limits the type of prey taken
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus web building spiders rarely capture caterpillars and crab spiders that ambush prey in flowers capture more bees butterflies and some flies than other insects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: groups of families that tend to take certain types of prey because of their prey capture methods are often called guilds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few spiders are more specialized in their prey capture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dysdera captures and eats sowbugs pillbugs and beetles while pirate spiders eat only other spiders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bolas spiders in the family araneidae use sex pheromone analogs to capture only the males of certain moth species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite their generally broad prey ranges spiders are one of the most important links in the regulation of the populations of insects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: every day on a meadow they devour over 10 g m&sup2 of insects and other arthropods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are many families of spiders and the ways that they catch prey are diverse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but whether they catch insects fish small mammals small birds or some other small form of life as soon as a spider makes contact with its prey it will attempt to bite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spiders bite their prey and occasionally animals that cause them pain or threaten them to do two things
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: first they inflict mechanical damage which in the case of a spider that is as large as or larger than its prey can be severe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: second they can choose to inject venom through their hollow fangs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many genera such as the widow spiders inject neurotoxins that can spread through the prey's entire body and interfere with vital body functions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other genera inject venom that operates to produce tissue damage at the site of the bite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: genera such as that of the brown recluse spider produce a necrotoxin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the necrotoxin is injected into prey where it causes the degradation of cell membranes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the larger victims that do not die from these attacks painful lesions over a fairly wide area of the body can remain active for fairly long periods of time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: digestion is carried out internally and externally
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spiders secrete digestive fluids into their prey from a series of ducts perforating their jaws
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these digestive fluids dissolve the prey's internal tissues
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then the spider feeds by sucking the partially digested fluids out
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spiders consume only liquid foods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many spiders will store prey temporarily
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: web weaving spiders that have made a shroud of silk to quiet their envenomed prey's death struggles will generally leave them in these shrouds and then consume them at their leisure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: main article spider web some spiders spin funnel shaped webs others make sheet webs and still others make the spiral orb webs which are most commonly associated with the order
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these webs may be made with sticky capture silk or with fluffy capture silk depending on the type of spider
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: webs may be in a vertical plane most orb webs a horizontal plane sheet webs or at any angle in between
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most commonly found in the sheet web spider families some webs will have loose irregular tangles of silk above them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these serve to disorient and knock down flying insects making them more vulnerable to being trapped in the web below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they may also help to protect the spider from aerial predators such as birds and wasps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spider after spinning its web will then wait on or near the web for a prey animal to become trapped
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spider can sense the impact and struggle of a prey animal by vibrations transmitted along the web lines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other species of spiders do not use webs for capturing prey directly instead pouncing from concealment e.g trapdoor spiders or running them down in open chase e.g wolf spiders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spiders do not usually adhere to their own webs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however they are not immune to their own glue
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of the strands of the web are sticky and others are not
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if a spider has chosen to wait along the outer edges of its web it may spin a non sticky prey or signal line to the web hub to monitor inter web movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spiders have to be careful to only climb on the non sticky strands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ability to spin webs allows a spider to catch prey without having to expend energy by running it down
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus it is a very efficient method of gathering food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however constructing the web is in itself an energetically costly process due to the large amount of protein required in the form of silk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition after a time the silk may lose its stickiness and thus become inefficient at capturing prey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is not uncommon for spiders to eat their own web daily to recoup some of the energy used in spinning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the silk proteins are thus recycled
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spider in the middle of the web also makes for a highly visible prey for birds and other predators
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many day hunting orb web spinners reduce this risk for example by hiding at the edge of the web with one foot on a signal line from the hub or by appearing to be inedible or unappetizing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the net casting spider balances the two methods of running and web spinning in its feeding habits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this spider weaves a small net which it attaches to its front legs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it then lurks in wait for potential prey and when such prey arrives lunges forward to wrap its victim in the net bite and paralyze it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hence this spider expends less energy catching prey than a primitive hunter such as the wolf spider
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it also avoids the energy loss of weaving a large orb web
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some spiders manage to use the signaling snare technique of a web without spinning a web at all
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several types of water dwelling spiders will rest their feet on the water's surface in much the same manner as an orb web user
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when an insect falls onto the water and is ensnared by surface tension the spider can detect the vibrations and run out to capture the prey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: key to bite severity it should also be noted that for healthy adults a bite by even the most toxic spiders on the list will require hours before death ensues if timely appropriate emergency medicine is administered victims should be expected to recover
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the scenario given in movies such as arachnophobia where bite victims die within minutes does not occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one exception to this is with very small children there is at least one recorded case of a small child dying within 15 minutes of a bite from a sydney funnel web spider that occurred before the development of an antivenin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: characterized by irregular messy looking tangled three dimensional non-sticky webs generally low and anchored to the ground or floor and wall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: commonly found in or near buildings some build webs in bushes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spider generally hangs in the center of the web upside down
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prey is generally ground dwelling insects such as ants or crickets in addition to small flying insects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: widows latrodectus spp a large cosmopolitan group all with relatively dangerous bites
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are relatively large about the size of a nickel burly looking house spiders generally dark often with a red mark on the glossy smooth abdomen either above or below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: examples examples * american house spider not dangerous
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these spiders spin the familiar spiral snare that most people think of as the spider web
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they range in size from quite large 6+ cm to very small <1 cm but all are quite harmless to humans beyond the shock entailed from walking into a face height web and having a large spider dangling from your nose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of the daytime hunters have a ferocious appearance with spines or large fangs but they are almost invariably inoffensive preferring to drop on a dragline to the ground when disturbed rather than bite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is a catch all category comprising members of several different groups that spin non sticky webs in a variety of structural styles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some the linyphiidae make various forms of bowl or dome shaped web with or without a flat sheet or a tangled web above or below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some make a flat platform extending from a funnel shaped retreat with generally a tangle of silk above the web
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the common northern hemisphere funnel web house or grass spiders are only distantly related to the notorious sydney funnel web spider and are generally considered to be quite harmless with one notable exception the hobo spider below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of the more primitive group atypidae may make tubular webs up the base of trees from inside which they bite insects that land on the webbing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these spiders look quite ferocious but are not generally considered to be particularly dangerous to humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is another catch all category that includes a diverse collection of spiders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some actively lure prey the bolas spiders and may capture them with a sticky ball of silk on a line others wait in a high traffic area and directly attack their prey from ambush
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dangerous spiders in the united states include widow spiders brown recluse spiders hobo spiders and yellow sac spiders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: none of these spiders will intentionally come after you but they should be removed from one's house to avoid accidental injury
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many authorities warn against spraying poisons indiscriminately to kill all spiders because doing so may actually remove one of the biological controls against incursions of the more dangerous species by ridding them of their competition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if dangerous spiders are present in your area then be mindful when you move cardboard boxes and other such objects that may have become the shelter of a poisonous spider
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is no need to be fearful just do not grab a spider
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the black widow spider is one of a number of widow spiders genus latrodectus that carry a neurotoxic venom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like many spiders widows have very poor vision jumping spiders and wolf spiders being notable exceptions and they move with difficulty when not on their web
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: widow spiders are large strong looking house spiders but still have relatively spindly legs and deep globular abdomens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the abdomen is dark and shiny and has one or several red spots either above or below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spots may take the form of an hourglass or two triangles point to point
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: male widows like most spiders are much smaller than the females and may have a variety of streaks and spots on a browner less globular abdomen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the males are generally considered to be much less dangerous if at all than the females
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: widows tend to be quite non aggressive but will bite if the web is disturbed and the spider feels threatened
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the venom although rarely life threatening produces very painful effects including muscle spasms and tetanus like contractions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a serious bite will often require a short hospital stay
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: children elderly and ill individuals are at most risk of serious effects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: brown recluse spiders or violin spiders from the dark violin shaped marking on the cephalothorax loxosceles reclusa are slow moving retiring spiders which wander about in dim areas and under things and so are more easily trapped against one's skin by clothing bed sheets etc even so most encounters with this spider occur from moving boxes or rooting about in closets or under beds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the range of this spider in the us is approximately the lower 2/3 of the country by the eastern 3/4 of the country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a number of related recluse spiders some non native introductions are found in southern california and nearby areas as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the hobo spider tegenaria agrestis may wander away from its web especially in the fall and thus come into contact with people and bite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this spider is found in the northwestern united states and throughout much of europe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: oddly enough in europe it is considered a harmless outdoor relative of the common house spider tegenaria domestica
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the yellow sac spiders chiracanthum sp take shelter in silk tubes during the daytime and generally come out to hunt at night
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these pale yellow or whitish spiders are often found in houses at the top of walls or wandering across ceilings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are also commonly found outdoors on foliage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the draglines they leave while hunting are one of the most common cob webs that are removed with broom and vacuum cleaner
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: people may unintentionally make contact with them in the dark and so be bitten
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however most people will live their entire lives in close proximity to them and never suffer a bite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: brown recluse spider bites can produce very severe local symptoms death of tissue around the wound and sometimes severe systemic symptoms including organ damage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the bites of hobo spiders and yellow sac spiders can cause both pain and necrosis tissue death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically all these bites are characterized by open sore like wounds that heal very slowly and may leave scarring
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has been suggested that steroid treatments may speed healing and reduce scarring
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is believed that many spider bites which are attributed often by physicians and other medical personnel to the brown recluse are in fact caused by the hobo spider if caused by a spider at all
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many brown recluse bites are reported in the us west coast states washington oregon and northern california where populations of brown recluse spiders have not been found
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are other species of spider in the genus loxosceles which are found in southern california and other southwestern states most of these species live in remote areas and are rarely encountered by humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bites of loxosceles spiders found in south america are more serious in their consequences than their north american relatives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the huntsman spiders have a worldwide reputation for scaring people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are large defend their nests and may move toward people and make threat displays
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they frequently enter houses and hunt over the walls and ceilings where they may run rapidly for long distances without pausing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when they actually do bite people the bites are very unpleasant but these spiders are not regarded as dangerous
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are quite common in parts of australia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: australian huntsman spiders are typically non aggressive except when defending their nests or their young
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is one spider in california and japan probably a huntsman tentatively identified as a member of the sparassidae family heteropoda venatoria which might run over and bite your finger if you touch the wall that it is clambering over
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that behavior may well occur because its eyesight is good enough to see movement and general shape but not sufficient to avoid mistaking something else for its natural prey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some people have reported being bitten by redback jumping spiders phidippus johnsoni
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most reports seem to be from california
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these relatively large alert jumping spiders have bright red abdomens the females have a black stripe and should be clearly visible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is unclear how the bites occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: accidental contact seems rather unlikely since jumping spiders have excellent vision and could easily avoid being brushed by a human hand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also unlikely that they would mistake a human finger for their natural prey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one source suggests that since they are quite attractive children may try to pick them up and in that way elicit a defensive bite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fortunately the worst consequences reported have been three to four days of discomfort with no permanent damage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like most of the larger spiders the consequences of a bite seem little different than a wasp or bee sting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since they do not frequent human habitations it should ordinarily be easy to avoid unpleasant contact with them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the brazilian wandering spider a ctenid spider and the australian venomous spiders such as the sydney funnel web spider a mygalomorph only distantly related to the araneomorph funnel web spiders frequently bite people and are regarded as among the most dangerous in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are quite aggressive spiders and are prone to biting when confronted rather than running away
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the sydney funnel web spider a large bulky black spider is restricted to a relatively small area around sydney australia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is unequivocally the most venomous spider in the world although phoneutria has the most neurologically active venom it is delivered in amounts rarely large enough to cause deaths
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are other dangerous species of atrax and hadronyche related to this spider in surrounding parts of australia including tasmania
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the males in this case have somewhat more potent venom than females and they also wander making them more likely to be encountered in summer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the brazilian wandering spider is a large brown spider rather like a north american wolf spider in appearance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it like several other more harmless spiders may hitch a ride in clusters of bananas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a result any large spider appearing in a bunch of bananas should be treated with due care
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: oddly many of the bites of this species are dry bites and no venom is released
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the spiders are as large as some small tarantulas and have fairly long fangs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while venom from either spider can be deadly to children and the infirm since the development of antivenom to the venoms of both were developed the funnel web spider in the mid 1980's and the wandering spider in 1996 no humans have died from their bites
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nevertheless any large spider which makes a threat display raising front legs rearing back to display fangs when encountered should be treated with caution especially in areas where these two types of spiders may be expected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: teori ieu museur kana kaputusan optimal nu bakal dipake dina kaayaan nu husus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most of decision theory is normative or prescriptive i.e it is concerned with identifying the best decision to take assuming an ideal decision taker who is fully informed able to compute with perfect accuracy and fully rational
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however since it is obvious that people do not typically behave in optimal ways there is also a related area of study which is a descriptive or positive discipline attempting to describe what people will actually do
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the normative optimal decision often creates hypotheses for testing against actual behaviour the two fields are closely linked
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: furthermore it is possible to relax the assumptions of perfect information rationality and so forth in various ways and produce a series of different prescriptions or predictions about behaviour allowing for further tests of the kind of decision making that occurs in practice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: decision theory is only relevant in decisions that are difficult for some reason
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few types of decision have attracted particular attention
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this area is concerned with the decision whether to have say one ton of guns and 3 tons of butter or 2 tons of guns and 1 ton of butter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is the classic subject of study of microeconomics and is rarely considered under the heading of decision theory but such choices are often in fact part of the issues that are considered within decision theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this area represents the heartland of decision theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: daniel bernoulli stated that when faced with a number of actions each of which could give rise to more than one possible outcome with different probabilities the rational procedure is to identify all possible outcomes determine their values positive or negative and the probabilities that they will result from each course of action and multiply the two to give an expected value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the action to be chosen should be the one that gives rise to the highest total expected value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in reality people do not behave like this at least if value is taken to mean objective financial value otherwise no one would either gamble or take out insurance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: within behavioural decision theory this has led to various dilutions of the expected value theory for example objective probabilities can be replaced by subjective estimates and objective values by subjective utilities giving rise to the subjectively expected utility or seu theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the prospect theory of daniel kahneman and amos tversky is another alternative to the expected value model within behavioural decision theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pascal's wager is a classic example of a choice under uncertainty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the uncertainty according to pascal is whether or not god exists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and the personal belief or non belief in god is the choice to be made
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this area is concerned with the kind of choice where different actions lead to outcomes that are realised at different points in time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if i receive a windfall of several thousand dollars i could spend it on an expensive holiday giving me immediate pleasure or i could invest it in a pension scheme giving me an income at some time in the future
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: what is the optimal thing to do
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the answer depends partly on factors such as the expected rates of interest and inflation my life expectancy and my confidence in the pensions industry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however even with all those factors taken into account human behaviour again deviates greatly from the predictions of prescriptive decision theory leading to alternative models in which for example objective interest rates are replaced by subjective discount rates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some decisions are difficult because of the need to take into account how other people in the situation will respond to the decision that is taken
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the analysis of such social decisions is the business of game theory and is not normally considered part of decision theory though it is closely related
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other areas of decision theory are concerned with decisions that are difficult simply because of their complexity or the complexity of the organisation that has to take them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in such cases the issue is not the deviation between real and optimal behaviour but the difficulty of determining the optimal behaviour in the first place
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <div style="float:right;margin-left:5px;text-align:center;padding-left:10px"> fungsi heaviside step ngaran nu dipake keur ngahargaan ka oliver heaviside nyaeta a fungsi diskontinyu nu mana nileyna nyaeta nol keur asupan negatip sarta hiji keur nu sejenna the function is used in the mathematics of signal processing to represent a signal that switches on at a specified time and stays switched on indefinitely
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its derivative is formally the dirac delta function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is the cumulative distribution function of a variabel acak which is almost surely 0
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see constant random variable the heaviside function is the integral of the dirac delta function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the value of h(0 is of very little importance since the function is often used within an integral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some writers give h(0 = 0 some h(0 = 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: h(0 = 0.5 is often used since it maximizes the symmetry of the function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this makes the definition where c is a positive offset in the x dimension of the transition from 0 to 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other words h 3 x = h(x − 3 would be zero until x = 3 and would transition to 1 for x > 3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the meaning of the subscript should be given in context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the question of the fourier transform of h is an interesting example for the theory of distributions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is often stated that it is 1/x up to a normalizing constant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but near x=0 that cannot be justified the definition must be given in terms of principal value limit and the transform isn't to be treated simply as a function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the corresponding convolution operator is the hilbert transform
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often an integral representation of the step function is useful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: independent components analysis ica is a mathematical method for separating a signal into its most probable additive subcomponent supposing the statistical independence of the source signals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this assumption is correct in most cases so the blind ica separation of a mixed signal gives very good results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also used for signals that are not supposed to be generated by a mixing for analysis purposes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the statistical method reveal hidden factors independent components presuming their non gaussianity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it uses principal components analysis as a first step
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: apply whitening of the data and then apply an iterative algorithm such as an adaptive filter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ica searches for orthogonal components that are mutually statistically independent to describe the input data matrix composed by the features vectors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can allow the reconstruction of source signals from several corrupted mixtures thereof
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the method is important to blind signal separation eeg analysis and fmri analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this concept can be extended to analyse non physical signals for instance ica has been aplied to discover discussions topics on a bag of news list archives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: numbers should be distinguished from numerals which are combinations of symbols used to represent numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the notation of numbers as a series of digits is discussed in numeral systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: people like to assign numbers to objects in order to have unique names
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are various numbering schemes for doing so.many languages have the concept of grammatical number an attribute of certain words and phrases that affects their syntactic usage and meaning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hasil nu paling anyar diana panalungtikan wilangan nyaeta hyperreal numbers jeung surreal numbers numangrupakeun perluasan tina wilangan nyata by adding infinitesimal and infinitely large numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while most real numbers have infinitely long expansions to the right of the decimal point one can also try to allow for infinitely long expansions to the left leading to the p adic numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for dealing with infinite collections the natural numbers have been generalized to the ordinal numbers and to the cardinal numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the former give the ordering of the collection the latter its size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the finite case the ordinal and cardinal numbers are equivalent they diverge in the infinite case the arithmetical operations of numbers such as addition subtraction multiplication and division are generalized in the branch of mathematics called abstract algebra one obtains the groups rings and fields
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many cultures the notation for the numbers one two and three is very similar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in roman numerals the corresponding numerals are i ii and iii and in chinese the same notation is used but with the tally marks written horizontally
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however neither the roman nor the chinese systems use simple tally marks for four
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the roman numeral for four is iv meaning one less than v which stands for five
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: evidently five has significance because of the number of digits on each human hand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however there is more here than mere human anatomy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: psychologists explain that the reason for the shift from a simple tally notation to one involving more symbols is the difficulty humans have in visually separating similar patterns with more than three identical elements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example it's hard to tell at a glance which is greater iiiiiiii or iiiiiii but it is easy to tell x from xi.the arabic numeral system uses modified tally marks for 1 2 and 3 1 has undergone only very minor modification and 2 and 3 are evidently based on horizontal lines written without lifting the pen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and again the simple tally is abandoned with the numeral for 4
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see list of numbers mathematical constants even and odd numbers negative and non negative numbers small numbers large numbers orders of magnitude numbers prime numbers umpteen

lines.value: saperti distribution n disebut stationary distribution atawa steady state distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: stationary distribution nyaeta eigenfunction tina fungsi conditional distribution nu pakait jeung eigenvalue 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whether or not there is a stationary distribution and whether or not it is unique if it does exist are determined by certain properties of the process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: irreducible means that every state is accessible from every other state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aperiodic means that there exists at least one state for which the transition from that state to itself is possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: positive recurrent means that the expected return time is finite for every state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes the terms indecomposable acyclic and persistent are used as synonyms for irreducible aperiodic and recurrent respectively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the markov chain is positive recurrent there exists a stationary distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if it is positive recurrent and irreducible there exists a unique stationary distribution and furthermore the process constructed by taking the stationary distribution as the initial distribution is ergodic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then the average of a function f over samples of the markov chain is equal to the average with respect to the stationary distribution where u n is the measure induced by n
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this makes it possible to approximate the stationary distribution by a histogram or other density estimate of a sequence of samples
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the state space is finite the transition probability distribution can be represented as a matrix called the transition matrix with the i j)'th element equal to : th power of the transition matrix
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that is if p is the one step transition matrix then p k is the transition matrix for the k step transition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: writing p for the transition matrix a stationary distribution is a vector which satisfies the equation in this case the stationary distribution is an eigenvector of the transition matrix associated with the eigenvalue 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the transition matrix p is positive recurrent irreducible and aperiodic then p k converges elementwise to a matrix in which each column is the unique stationary distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a transition matrix which is positive that is every element of the matrix is positive is irreducible aperiodic and positive recurrent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a matrix is a stochastic matrix if and only if it is the matrix of transition probabilities of some markov chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: markov chains are used to model various processes in queueing theory and statistics and can also be used as a signal model in entropy coding techniques such as arithmetic coding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: markov chains also have many biological applications particularly population processes which are useful in modelling processes that are at least analogous to biological populations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: markov chains have been used in bioinformatics as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example is the genemark algorithm for coding region gene prediction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: markov processes can also be used to generate superficially real looking text given a sample document they are used in various pieces of recreational parody generator software see jeff harrison
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for maps on a computer display e.g from the web or locally stored on cd rom or harddisk zooming in means enlarging the scale either by showing a smaller area in the same viewing window or by showing the same area in a larger viewing window and one of the following for a single raster graphics image the second applies until the pixels in the image file correspond to the pixels of the display on further zooming in the third applies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a pdf file typically the second applies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the increase in detail is of course limited to the information contained in the file enlarging a curve it may eventually become a series of straight line segments or other standard geometric figures such as arcs of circles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a variation of the third possibility is that interpolation is performed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: text is not necessarily enlarged when zooming in
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly a road represented by a double line may or may not become wider when one zooms in
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a variation of the first possibility above is that more text is displayed such as more town names but that for the rest of the image the second applies

lines.value: sacara informal proses stokastik mibanda sipat markov if the conditional probability distribution of future states of the process given the present state depends only upon the current state and conditionally independent of the past states the path of the process given the present state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a process with the markov property is usually called a markov process and may be described as markovian
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mathematically if x(t t > 0 is a stochastic process the markov property states that and otherwise are termed time- inhomogeneous or time- nonhomogeneous
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: homogeneous markov processes usually being simpler than inhomogeneous ones form the most important class of markov processes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some cases apparently non markovian processes may still have markovian representations constructed by expanding the concept of the current and future states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: let x be a non markovian process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then we define a process y such that each state of y represents a time interval of states of x i.e mathematically if y has the markov property then it is a markovian representation of x in this case x is also called a second order markov process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: higher order markov processes are defined analogously
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example of an non markovian process with a markovian representation is a moving average deret waktu
lines.name: Sundanese
