lines.value: virus imunodefisiensi manusa anu katelah hiv human immunodeficiency virus mangrupa retrovirus nu utamana nginfeksi bagian vital sistim imun manusa kayaning sel t cd4+ makropag jeung sel dendritik
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ieu virus oge boh sacara langsung atawa henteu ngancurkeun sel t cd4+
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ku sabab sel t cd4+ t dipikabutuh pikeun jalanna sistim imun mun sel ieu geus diancurkeun ku hiv sistim imun bakal tumpur antukna ngabalukarkeun kasakit nu katelah aids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!hiv oge narajang langsung kana jero also directly attacks organs such as the kidneys the heart and the brain leading to acute renal failure cardiomyopathy dementia and encephalopathy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of the problems faced by people infected with hiv result from failure of the immune system to protect from opportunistic infections and cancers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv is transmitted through direct contact of a mucous membrane with a bodily fluid containing hiv such as blood semen vaginal fluid preseminal fluid or breast milk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this transmission can come in the form of penetrative anal or vaginal sex oral sex blood transfusion contaminated needles exchange between mother and infant during pregnancy childbirth or breastfeeding or other exposure to one of the above bodily fluids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv is hypothesized to have originated in southern cameroon after jumping from wild chimpanzees pan troglodytes troglodytes to humans during the twentieth century and is now a pandemic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as of january 2006 the joint united nations programme on hiv/aids unaids and the world health organization who estimate that aids has killed more than 25 million people since it was first recognized on december 1 1981 making it one of the most destructive pandemics in recorded history
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2005 alone aids claimed an estimated 2.4 3.3 million lives of which more than 570000 were children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a third of these deaths are occurring in sub saharan africa retarding economic growth by destroying human capital
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: current estimates say that about 28 million people have died and that hiv is set to infect 90 million people in africa resulting in a minimum estimate of 18 million orphans in africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: antiretroviral treatment reduces both the mortality and the morbidity of hiv infection but routine access to antiretroviral medication is not available in all countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv/aids stigma is more severe than that associated with other life threatening conditions and extends beyond the disease itself to providers and even volunteers involved with the care of people living with hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1983 scientists led by luc montagnier at the pasteur institute in france first discovered the virus that causes aids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they called it lymphadenopathy associated virus lav
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a year later a team led by robert gallo of the united states confirmed the discovery of the virus but they renamed it human t lymphotropic virus type iii htlv-iii
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dual discovery led to considerable scientific fall out and it was not until president mitterrand of france and president reagan of the usa met that the major issues were ironed out
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1986 both the french and the us names were dropped in favour of the new term human immunodeficiency virus hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv is a member of the genus lentivirus part of the family of retroviridae
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lentiviruses have many common morphologies and biological properties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many species are infected by lentiviruses which are characteristically responsible for long duration illnesses associated with a long period of incubation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lentiviruses are transmitted as single stranded positive sense enveloped rna viruses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: upon infection of the target cell the viral rna genome is converted to double stranded dna by a virally encoded reverse transcriptase which is present in the virus particle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this viral dna is then integrated into the cellular dna for replication using cellular machinery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once the virus enters the cell two pathways are possible either the virus becomes latent and the infected cell continues to function or the virus becomes active replicates and a large number of virus particles are liberated which can infect other cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two species of hiv infect humans hiv 1 and hiv 2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv 1 is the more virulent and easily transmitted and is the source of the majority of hiv infections throughout the world hiv 2 is largely confined to west africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: both species originated in west and central africa jumping from primates to humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv 1 has evolved from a simian immunodeficiency virus sivcpz found in the chimpanzee subspecies pan troglodytes troglodytes found in southern cameroon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kinshasa in the democratic republic of congo has the greatest genetic diversity of hiv 1 so far discovered suggesting that the virus has been there longer than anywhere else
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv 2 crossed species from a different strain of siv found in sooty mangabey monkeys in guinea bissau
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is possible that hiv 1 entered the human populations in the 1930's
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another controversial possibility for the origin of hiv/aids was discussed in a 1992 rolling stone magazine article by freelance journalist tom curtis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he put forward the theory that aids was inadvertently caused in the late 1950s in the belgian congo by hilary koprowski's research into a polio vaccine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although subsequently retracted due to libel issues surrounding its claims the rolling stone article encouraged another freelance journalist edward hooper to travel to africa for seven years of research into this subject
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hooper's research resulted in his publishing a 1999 book the river in which he alleged that an experimental oral polio vaccine prepared using chimpanzee kidney tissue was the route through which siv mutated into hiv and started the human aids epidemic some time between 1957 and 1959
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the beginning of the pandemic three main transmission routes of hiv have been identified the use of physical barriers such as the latex condom is widely advocated to reduce the sexual transmission of hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recently it has been proposed that male circumcision may reduce the risk of hiv transmission but many experts believe that it is premature to recommend male circumcision as part of hiv prevention programs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for more details on this topic see aids transmission and prevention
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: approximately half of those infected with hiv do not know their hiv status until an aids diagnosis is made with an hiv test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: donor blood and blood products used in medicine and medical research are screened for hiv using such a test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typical hiv tests including the hiv enzyme immunoassay and the western blot assay detect hiv antibodies in serum plasma oral fluid dried blood spot or urine of patients
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the time between initial infection and the development of detectable antibodies against hiv can vary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is called the window period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is why it can take 6-12 months to to seroconvert and test positive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: commercially available tests to detect other hiv antigens hiv rna and hiv dna in order to detect hiv infection prior to the development of detectable antibodies are available
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however for the diagnosis of hiv infection these assays are not specifically approved but are nonetheless routinely used in developed countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: infection with hiv 1 is associated with a progressive loss of cd4+ t cells lymphocytes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this rate of loss can be measured and is used to determine the stage of infection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the loss of cd4+ t cells is linked with an increase in viral load
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the clinical course of hiv infection generally includes three stages primary infection clinical latency and aids figure 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv plasma levels during all stages of infection range from just 50 to 11 million virions per ml
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: primary or acute infection is a period of rapid viral replication that immediately follows the individual's exposure to hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during primary hiv infection most individuals 80 to 90% develop an acute syndrome characterised by flu like symptoms of fever malaise lymphadenopathy pharyngitis headache myalgia and sometimes a rash
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: within an average of three weeks after transmission of hiv 1 a broad hiv 1 specific immune response occurs that includes seroconversion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because of the nonspecific nature of these illnesses it is often not recognized as a sign of hiv infection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even if patients go to their doctors or a hospital they will often be misdiagnosed as having one of the more common infectious diseases with the same symptoms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since not all patients develop it and since the same symptoms can be caused by many other common diseases it cannot be used as an indicator of hiv infection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however recognizing the syndrome is important because the patient is much more infectious during this period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a strong immune defense reduces the number of viral particles in the blood stream marking the start of the infection's clinical latency stage figure 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: clinical latency can vary between two weeks and 20 years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during this early phase of infection hiv is active within lymphoid organs where large amounts of virus become trapped in the follicular dendritic cells fdc network
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the surrounding tissues that are rich in cd4+ t cells also become infected and viral particles accumulate both in infected cells and as free virus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: individuals who have entered into this phase are still infectious
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aids is the most severe manifestation of infection with hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: acute hiv infection progresses over time to clinical latent hiv infection and then to early symptomatic hiv infection and later to aids which is identified on the basis of certain infections
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for more details on this topic see aids diagnosis and aids symptoms and complications
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv is different in structure from previously described retroviruses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is around 120 nm in diameter 120 billionths of a meter around 60 times smaller than a red blood cell and roughly spherical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv 1 is composed of two copies of single stranded rna enclosed by a conical capsid which is in turn surrounded by a plasma membrane that is formed from part of the host cell membrane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other enzymes contained within the virion particle include reverse transcriptase integrase and protease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv has several major genes coding for structural proteins that are found in all retroviruses and several nonstructural accessory genes that are unique to hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gag gene provides the physical infrastructure of the virus pol provides the basic enzymes by which retroviruses reproduce the env gene supplies the proteins essential for viral attachment and entry into a target cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the accessory proteins tat rev nef vif vpr and vpu enhance virus production
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although called accessory proteins tat and rev are essential for virus replication
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some strains of hiv a mutation causes the production of an alternate accessory protein tev from the fusion of tat rev and env
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gp120 and gp41 proteins both encoded by the env gene enable the virus to attach to and fuse with target cells to initiate the infectious cycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: both especially gp120 have been considered as targets of future treatments or vaccines against hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term viral tropism refers to the cell type that the virus infects and replicates in
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv can infect a variety of cells such as cd4+ helper t cells and macrophages that express the cd4 molecule on its surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv 1 entry to macrophages and t helper cells is mediated not only through interaction of the virion envelope glycoproteins gp120 with the cd4 molecule on the target cells but also with its chemokine coreceptors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: macrophage m-tropic strains of hiv 1 or non syncitia inducing strains nsi use the beta chemokine receptor ccr5 for entry and are thus able to replicate in macrophages and cd4+ t cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the normal ligands for this receptor rantes macrophage inflammatory protein mip)-1-beta and mip 1 alpha are able to suppress hiv 1 infection in vitro
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this ccr5 coreceptor is used by almost all primary hiv 1 isolates regardless of viral genetic subtype
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: indeed macrophages play a key role in several critical aspects of hiv disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they appear to be the first cells infected by hiv and perhaps the very source of hiv production when cd4+ cells are markedly depleted in the patient
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: macrophages and microglial cells are the cells infected by hiv in the central nervous system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in tonsils and adenoids of hiv infected patients macrophages fuse into multinucleated giant cells that produce copious amounts of virus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: t tropic isolates or syncitia inducing si strains replicate in primary cd4+ t cells as well as in macrophages and use the alpha chemokine receptor cxcr4 for entry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the alpha chemokine sdf 1 a ligand for cxcr4 suppresses replication of t tropic hiv 1 isolates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it does this by down regulating the expression of cxcr4 on the surface of these cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: viruses that use only the ccr5 receptor are termed r5 those that only use cxcr4 are termed x4 and those that use both x4r5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the use of coreceptor alone does not explain viral tropism as not all r5 viruses are able to use ccr5 on macrophages for a productive infection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some people are resistant to certain strains of hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example of this is people with the ccr5-δ32 mutation these people are resistant to infection with r5 virus as the mutation does not allow hiv to bind to this coreceptor impeding its ability to infect the target cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv can also infect a subtype of dendritic cells mdc 1 which probably constitute a major reservoir that maintains infection when t helper cell numbers have declined to extremely low levels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the interaction between the glycoprotein gp120 on the hiv virion and its receptor cd4 on the target cell provokes conformational changes in gp120
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this exposes a region of gp120 the v3 loop which binds to a cytokine receptor on the target cell such as ccr5 or cxcr4 depending on the strain of hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: without a coreceptor fusion does not take place explaining why hiv favors some types of cd4+ cells over others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the change in gp120's shape also exposes a portion of the gp41 glycoprotein which was previously buried in the viral membrane and loosely bound to gp120
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a fusion peptide within gp41 causes the fusion of the viral envelope and the host cell envelope allowing the capsid to enter the target cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the exact mechanism by which gp41 causes the fusion is still largely unknown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once hiv has bound to the target cell the hiv rna and various enzymes including but not limited to reverse transcriptase integrase and protease are injected into the cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once the viral capsid has entered the cell an enzyme called reverse transcriptase liberates the single stranded +)rna from the attached viral proteins and copies it into a negatively sensed viral complementary dna of 9 kb pairs cdna figure 2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this process of reverse transcription is extremely error prone and it is during this step that mutations such as drug resistance are likely to arise
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the reverse transcriptase then makes a complementary dna strand to form a double stranded viral dna intermediate vdna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this new vdna is then transported into the cell nucleus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the integration of the proviral dna into the host genome is carried out by another viral enzyme called integrase
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is called the latent stage of hiv infection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to actively produce virus certain transcription factors need to be present in the cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most important is called nf kb nf kappa b and is present once the t cell becomes activated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that those cells most likely to be killed by hiv are in fact those currently fighting infection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: initially the integrated provirus is copied to mrna which is then spliced into smaller chunks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these small chunks produce the regulatory proteins tat which encourages new virus production and rev as rev accumulates it gradually starts to inhibit mrna splicing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at this stage the structural proteins gag and env are produced from the full length mrna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: additionally the full length rna is actually the virus genome so it binds to the gag protein and is packaged into new virus particles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: interestingly hiv 1 and hiv 2 appear to package their rna differently hiv 1 will bind to any appropriate rna whereas hiv 2 will preferentially bind to the mrna which was used to create the gag protein itself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this may mean that hiv 1 is better able to mutate hiv-1 causes aids faster than hiv 2 and is the majority species of the virus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the final step of the viral cycle assembly of new hiv 1 virions begins at the plasma membrane of the host cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the env polyprotein gp160 goes through the endoplasmic reticulum and is transported to the golgi complex where it is cleaved by protease and processed into the two hiv envelope glycoproteins gp41 and gp120
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are transported to the plasma membrane of the host cell where gp41 anchors the gp120 to the membrane of the infected cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gag p55 and gag pol p160 polyproteins also associate with the inner surface of the plasma membrane along with the hiv genomic rna as the forming virion begins to bud from the host cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: maturation either occurs in the forming bud or in the immature virion after it buds from the host cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during maturation hiv proteases proteinases cleave the polyproteins into individual functional hiv proteins and enzymes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the various structural components then assemble to produce a mature hiv virion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this step can be inhibited by drugs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the virus is then able to infect another cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the major characteristics of hiv is its high genetic variability as a result of its fast replication cycle and the high error rate and recombinogenic properties of reverse transcriptase
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that different genomic combinations may be generated within an individual who is infected by genetically different hiv strains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recombination results when a cell is simultaneously infected by two different strains of hiv and one rna transcript from two different viral strains are encapsidated into the same virion particle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this virion then infects a new cell where it undergoes replication
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during this phase the reverse transcriptase by jumping back and forth between the two different rna templates will generate a newly synthesized retroviral dna sequence that is a recombinant between the two parental genomes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this recombination is most obvious when it occurs between subtypes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: three groups of hiv 1 have been identified on the basis of differences in env m n and o figure 4
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: group m is the most prevalent and is subdivided into eight subtypes based on the whole genome that are each geographically distinct
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most prevalent are subtypes b found predominantly in north america and europe a and d found predominantly in africa and c found predominantly in africa and asia figure 5 these subtypes form branches in the phylogenetic tree representing the lineage of the m group of hiv 1 figure 4
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: coinfection with distinct subtypes gives rise to circulating recombinant forms crfs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2000 the last year in which an analysis of global subtype prevalence was made 47.2% of infections worldwide were of subtype c 26.7% were of subtype a/crf02_ag 12.3% were of subtype b 5.3% were of subtype d 3.2% were of crf_ae and the remaining 5.3% were composed of other subtypes and crfs figure 5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: almost 95% of all hiv research currently taking place is focused on subtype b while a few laboratories focus on other subtypes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hiv infection is a chronic infectious disease that can be treated but not yet cured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are effective means of preventing complications and delaying progression to aids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the present time not all persons infected with hiv have progressed to aids but it is generally believed that the majority will
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: people with hiv infection need to receive education about the disease and treatment so that they can be active partners in decision making with their health care provider
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a combination of several antiretroviral agents termed highly active anti retroviral therapy haart has been highly effective in reducing the number of hiv particles in the blood stream as measured by a blood test called the viral load
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can improve t cell counts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is not a cure for hiv and people on haart with suppressed levels of hiv can still transmit the virus to others through sex or sharing of needles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is good evidence that if the levels of hiv remain suppressed and the cd4 count remains greater than 200 then the quality and length of life can be significantly improved and prolonged
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: improved antiretroviral inhibitors against proteins such as reverse transcriptase integrase and tat are being researched and developed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the most promising new therapies is a new class of drugs called fusion or entry inhibitors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: current recommendations for treatment include at least a three drug effective regime to induce complete cease of viral replication and reduce the incidence of new mutations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: current drug classes include nnrti nrti ntrti pi fi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each of the drugs in these classes represent individual pharmacodynamics and toxicities requiring expert knowledge to appropriately select and dose an effective combination
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: post exposure prophylaxis pep with a course of antiviral drugs is also thought to reduce the risk of seroconversion after high risk exposure unprotected anal or vaginal sex to hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to be effective it must be started as soon as possible after exposure and no later than 72 hours post exposure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the treatment for hiv lasts four weeks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while there is compelling data to suggest that pep after hiv exposure is extremely effective there have been cases where it has failed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as yet no vaccine has been developed to prevent hiv infection or disease in people who are not yet infected with hiv but the potential worldwide public health benefits of such a preventive vaccine are vast
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: researchers in many countries are seeking to produce such a vaccine including through the international aids vaccine initiative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unaids and the who estimate that aids has killed more than 25 million people since it was first recognized in 1981 making it one of the most destructive epidemics in recorded history
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite recent improved access to antiretroviral treatment and care in many regions of the world the aids epidemic claimed an estimated 2.8 million between 2.4 and 3.3 million lives in 2005 of which more than half a million 570000 were children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: globally between 33.4 and 46 million people currently live with hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2005 between 3.4 and 6.2 million people were newly infected and between 2.4 and 3.3 million people with aids died an increase from 2004 and the highest number since 1981
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sub saharan africa remains by far the worst affected region with an estimated 21.6 to 27.4 million people currently living with hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two million [1.5-3.0 million] of them are children younger than 15 years of age
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more than 64% of all people living with hiv are in sub saharan africa as are more than three quarters 76% of all women living with hiv
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2005 there were 12.0 million [10.6-13.6 million] aids orphans living in sub saharan africa 2005
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: south & south east asia are second worst affected with 15%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aids accounts for the deaths of 500000 children in this region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two thirds of hiv/aids infections in asia occur in india with an estimated 5.7 million infections estimated 3.4 9.4 million 0.9% of population surpassing south africa's estimated 5.5 million 4.9-6.1 million 11.9% of population infections making it the country with the highest number of hiv infections in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the latest evaluation report of the world bank's operations evaluation department assesses the development effectiveness of the world bank's country level hiv/aids assistance defined as policy dialogue analytic work and lending with the explicit objective of reducing the scope or impact of the aids epidemic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is the first comprehensive evaluation of the world bank's hiv/aids support to countries from the beginning of the epidemic through mid 2004
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because the bank's assistance is for implementation of government programmes by government it provides important insights on how national aids programmes can be made more effective
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the development of haart as effective therapy for hiv infection and aids has substantially reduced the death rate from this disease in those areas where it is widely available
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has created the misperception that the disease has gone away
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fact as the life expectancy of persons with aids has increased in countries where haart is widely used the number of persons living with aids has increased substantially
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states the number of persons with aids increased from about 35000 in 1988 to over 220000 in 1996
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 35 african nations with the highest prevalence average life expectancy is 48.3 years 6.5 years less than it would be without the disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the eleven countries in africa with prevalence rates above 13% life expectancy is 47.7 years 11.0 years less than would be expected without hiv/aids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in africa the number of mtct and the prevalence of aids is beginning to reverse decades of steady progress in child survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: countries such as uganda are attempting to curb the mtct epidemic by offering vct voluntary counselling and testing pmtct prevention of mother to child transmission and anc ante-natal care services which include the distribution of antiretroviral therapy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a minority of scientists and activists question the connection between hiv and aids or the existence of hiv or the validity of current testing methods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these claims are met with resistance by and often evoke frustration and hostility from most of the scientific community who accuse the dissidents of ignoring evidence in favor of hiv's role in aids and irresponsibly posing a dangerous threat to public health by their continued activities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dissidents assert that the current mainstream approach to aids based on hiv causation has resulted in inaccurate diagnoses psychological terror toxic treatments and a squandering of public funds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the debate and controversy regarding this issue from the early 1980s to the present has provoked heated emotions and passions from both sides
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--at extremely high doses tobacco becomes hallucinogenic accordingly native americans generally did not use the drug recreationally
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rather it was often consumed in extraordinarily high quantities and used as an entheogen generally this was done only by experienced shamans or medicine men
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to being smoked uncured tobacco was often eaten drunk as tobacco juice or used in enemas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early missionaries often reported on the state caused by tobacco but as it spread into the west it was no longer used in such large quantities or for entheogenic purposes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: religious use of tobacco is still common among many indigenous peoples particularly those of south america
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the arrival of europeans tobacco became one of the primary products fueling the colonization of the future american south long before the creation of the united states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the initial colonial expansion fueled by the desire to increase tobacco production was one cause of the first colonial conflicts with native americans and became a driving factor for the use of african slaves labor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1609 john rolfe arrived at the jamestown settlement in virginia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he is credited as the first man to successfully raise tobacco for commercial use at jamestown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tobacco raised in virginia at that time nicotiana rustica was not to the liking of the europeans but rolfe had brought some seed for nicotiana tabacum with him from bermuda
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shortly after arriving his first wife died and he married pocahontas a daughter of chief powhatan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although most of the settlers wouldn't touch the tobacco crop rolfe was able to make his fortune farming it for export at varina farms plantation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when he left for england with pocahontas he was wealthy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when rolfe returned to jamestown following pocahontas's death in england he continued to improve the quality of tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by 1620 40000 pounds of tobacco were shipped to england
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the time john rolfe died in 1622 jamestown was thriving as a producer of tobacco and jamestown's population would top 4000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tobacco led to the importation of the colony's first black slaves as well as women from england in 1619
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the importation of tobacco into europe was not without resistance and controversy even in the 17th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: king james i of england james vi of scotland wrote a famous polemic titled a counterblaste to tobacco in 1604 published in 1672
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in his essay the king denounced tobacco use as [a] custome lothsome to the eye hatefull to the nose harmefull to the braine dangerous to the lungs and in the blacke stinking fume thereof neerest resembling the horrible stigian smoke of the pit that is bottomelesse in that same year an english statute was enacted that placed a heavy protective tariff on every pound of tobacco brought into england
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: throughout the 17th and 18th centuries tobacco continued to be the cash crop of the virginia colony along with the carolinas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: large tobacco warehouses filled the areas near the wharfs of new thriving towns such as richmond and manchester at the fall line head of navigation on the james river and petersburg on the appomattox river
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: until 1883 tobacco excise tax accounted for one third of internal revenue collected by the united states government
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a historian of the american south in the late 1860s reported on typical usage in the region where it was grown the chewing of tobacco was well nigh universal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this habit had been widespread among the agricultural population of america both north and south before the war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: soldiers had found the quid a solace in the field and continued to revolve it in their mouths upon returning to their homes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: out of doors where his life was principally led the chewer spat upon his lands without offence to other men and his homes and public buildings were supplied with spittoons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: brown and yellow parabolas were projected to right and left toward these receivers but very often without the careful aim which made for cleanly living
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even the pews of fashionable churches were likely to contain these familiar conveniences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the large numbers of southern men and these were of the better class officers in the confederate army and planters worth $20000 or more and barred from general amnesty who presented themselves for the pardon of president johnson while they sat awaiting his pleasure in the ante room at the white house covered its floor with pools and rivulets of their spittle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an observant traveller in the south in 1865 said that in his belief seven tenths of all persons above the age of twelve years both male and female used tobacco in some form
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: women could be seen at the doors of their cabins in their bare feet in their dirty one piece cotton garments their chairs tipped back smoking pipes made of corn cobs into which were fitted reed stems or goose quills
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: boys of eight or nine years of age and half grown girls smoked
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: women and girls dipped in their houses on their porches in the public parlors of hotels and in the streets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a lucrative crop tobacco has been the subject of a great deal of biological and genetic research
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the economic impact of tobacco mosaic disease was the impetus that led to the isolation of tobacco mosaic virus the first virus to be identified the fortunate coincidence that it is one of the simplest virii and can self assemble from purified nucleic acid and protein led in turn to the rapid advancement of the field of virology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 1946 nobel prize in chemistry was shared by wendell meredith stanley for his 1935 work crystallizing the virus and showing that it still remains active
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tobacco seeds are started very early in the year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the seeds are scattered onto the surface of the soil as their germination is activated by light
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in colonial virginia seedbeds were fertilized with wood ash or animal manure frequently powdered horse manure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: seedbeds were then covered with branches to protect the young plants from frost damage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these plants were left to grow until around april
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the nineteenth century young plants came under increasing attack from the flea beetle epitrix cucumeris or epitrix pubescens causing destruction of half the united states tobacco crop in 1876
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the years afterward many experiments were attempted and discussed to control the flea beetle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by 1880 it was discovered that replacing the branches with a frame covered by thin fabric would effectively protect plants from the beetle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this practice spread until it became ubiquitous in the 1890s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today in the united states unlike other countries tobacco is often fertilized with the mineral apatite in order to partially starve the plant for nitrogen which changes the taste
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this together with the use of licorice and other additives accounts for the different flavor of american cigarettes from those available in other countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is however some suggestion that this may have adverse health effects attributable to the polonium content of apatite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the plants have reached a certain height they are transplanted into fields
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was originally done by making a relatively large hole in the tilled earth with a tobacco peg then placing the small plant in the hole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various mechanical tobacco planters were invented throughout the late 19th and early 20th century to automate this process making a hole fertilizing it and guiding a plant into the hole with one motion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once the tobacco plants are growing well they will begin to produce shoots from the joint of each leaf with the stalk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these secondary shoots &mdash known as suckers &mdash are undesirable as they divert energy that could be directed into the leaves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are removed in a process known as suckering sometimes spelled succoring in older writing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: generally this is done by hand several times during the season
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recently anti suckering compounds have come into use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at a certain stage of maturity the plant will produce a flower cluster from its tip as well as the tips of any suckers that remain on the plant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in order to divert more energy into the leaves the plant is topped &mdash the top is cut off
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tobacco is harvested in one of two ways
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the oldest method the entire plant is harvested at once by cutting off the stalk at the ground with a curved knife
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the nineteenth century bright tobacco began to be harvested by pulling individual leaves off the stalk as they ripened
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the leaves ripen from the ground upwards so a field of tobacco may go through several pullings before the tobacco is entirely harvested and the stalks may be turned into the soil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cropping or pulling are terms for pulling leaves off tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: leaves are cropped as they ripen from the bottom of the stalk up
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first crop at the very bottom of the stalks are called sand lugs as they are often against the ground and are coated with dirt splashed up when it rains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sand lugs weigh the most and are most difficult to work with
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally workers cropped the tobacco and placed it on mule pulled sleds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eventually tractors with wagons were used to transport leaves to the stringer an apparatus which uses twine to sew leaves onto a stick
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some farmers use tobacco harvesters basically a trailer pulled behind a tractor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the harvester is a wheeled sled or trailer that has seats for the croppers to sit on and seats just in front of these for the stringers to sit on
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the croppers pull the leaves off in handfuls and pass these to the stringer who loops twine around the handfuls of tobacco and hangs them on a long wooden square pole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditionally the croppers down in the dark and wet with their faces getting slapped by the huge tobacco leaves were men and the stringers seated on the higher elevated seats were women
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the harvester has places for 4 teams of workers 8 people cropping and stringing plus a packer who takes the heavy strung poles of wet green tobacco from the stringers and packs them onto the pallet section of the harvester plus a driver making the total crew of each harvester 10 people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: interestingly the outer seats are suspended from the harvester slung out over to fit into the aisles of tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as these seats are suspended it is important to balance the weight of the 2 outside teams similar to a playground see saw
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having too heavy or light a person in an unbalanced combination often results in the harvester tipping over especially when turning around at the end of a lane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: water tanks are a common feature on the harvester due to heat and danger of de hydration for the workers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: salt tablets sometimes get used as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pests of tobacco include the moths endoclita excrescens manduca sexta and manduca quinquemaculata
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other lepidoptera whose larvae use tobacco as a food plant include angle shades cabbage moth mouse moth nutmeg moth setaceous hebrew character and turnip moth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dry tobacco leaves and cigarettes are sometimes used as food for the cigarette beetle lasioderma serricorne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cut plants or pulled leaves are immediately transferred to tobacco barns where they will be cured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: curing methods varies with the type of tobacco grown and tobacco barn design varies accordingly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: air cured tobacco is hung in well ventilated barns and allowed to dry over a period of weeks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fire cured tobacco is hung in large barns where smoldering fires of hardwoods are kept burning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: flue cured tobacco was originally strung onto tobacco sticks which were hung from tier poles in curing barns aus kilns also traditionally called oasts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these barns have flues which run from externally fed fire boxes to the roof heat curing the tobacco without exposing it to smoke
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditional curing barns in the us are falling into disuse as the trend toward more efficient prefabricated metal bulk bars allows greater efficiency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: curing and subsequent aging allows for the slow oxidation and degradation of carotenoids in tobacco leaf
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this produces certain compounds in the tobacco leaves very similar and give a sweet hay tea rose oil or fruity aromatic flavor that contribute to the smoothness of the smoke
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: starch is converted to sugar which glycates protein and is oxidized into advanced glycation endproducts ages a caramelization process that also adds flavor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: inhalation of these ages in tobacco smoke contributes to atherosclerosis and cancer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unaged or low quality tobacco is often flavoured with these naturally occurring compounds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tobacco flavoring is a significant part of a multi million dollar industry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the aging process continues for a period of months and often extends into the post curing process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after tobacco is cured it is moved from the curing barn into a storage area for processing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if whole plants were cut the leaves are removed from the tobacco stalks in a process called stripping
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for both cut and pulled tobacco the leaves are then sorted into different grades
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in colonial times the tobacco was then prized into hogsheads for transportation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in bright tobacco regions prizing was replaced by stacking wrapped hands into loose piles to be sold at auction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today most cured tobacco is baled before sales under contract
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aromatic fire cured smoking tobacco is a robust variety of tobacco used as a condimental for pipe blends
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is cured by smoking over gentle fires
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states it is grown in the western part of tennessee western kentucky and in virginia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: latakia is produced from oriental varieties of n
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tabacum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the leaves are cured and smoked over smoldering fires of local hardwoods and aromatic shrubs in cyprus and syria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: latakia has a pronounced flavor and a very distinctive aroma and is used in the so called balkan and english style pipe tobacco blends
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fire cured tobacco grown in kentucky and tennessee is used in some chewing tobaccos moist snuff some cigarettes and as a condiment leaf in pipe tobacco blends
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has a rich slightly floral taste and adds body and aroma to the blend
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prior to the american civil war the tobacco grown in the us was almost entirely fire cured dark leaf
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was planted in fertile lowlands used a robust variety of leaf and was fire cured or air cured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometime after the war of 1812 demand for a milder lighter more aromatic tobacco arose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ohio and maryland both innovated quite a bit with milder varieties of the tobacco plant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: farmers around the country experimented with different curing processes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but the breakthrough didn't come until 1854
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it had been noticed for centuries that sandy highland soil produced thinner weaker plants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: captain abisha slade of caswell county north carolina had a good deal of infertile sandy soil and planted the new gold leaf varieties on it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: slade owned a slave stephen who accidentally produced the first real bright tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he used charcoal to restart a fire used to cure the crop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the surge of heat turned the leaves yellow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: using that discovery slade developed a system for producing bright tobacco cultivating on poorer soils and using charcoal for heat curing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: news spread through the area pretty quickly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the worthless sandy soil of the appalachian piedmont was suddenly profitable and people rapidly developed flue curing techniques a more efficient way of smoke free curing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the outbreak of the war the town of danville virginia actually had developed a bright leaf market for the surrounding area in caswell county north carolina and pittsylvania county virginia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: danville was also the main railway head for confederate soldiers going to the front
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these brought bright tobacco with them from danville to the lines traded it with each other and union soldiers and developed quite a taste for it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the end of the war the soldiers went home and suddenly there was a national market for the local crop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: caswell and pittsylvania counties were the only two counties in the south that experienced an increase in total wealth after the war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1864 george webb of brown county ohio planted red burley seeds he had purchased and found that a few of the seedlings had a whitish sickly look
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he transplanted them to the fields anyway where they grew into mature plants but retained their light color
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cured leaves had an exceedingly fine texture and were exhibited as a curiosity at the market in cincinnati
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following year he planted ten acres 40000 m² from seeds from those plants which brought a premium at auction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the air cured leaf was found to be mild tasting and more absorbent than any other variety
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: white burley as it was later called became the main component in chewing tobacco american blend pipe tobacco and american style cigarettes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the white part of the name is seldom used today since red burley a dark air cured variety of the mid 1800s no longer exists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is not well known that the northern us state of connecticut is also one of the important tobacco growing regions of the country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: long before europeans arrived in the area native americans harvested wild tobacco plants that grew along the banks of the connecticut river
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today the connecticut river valley north of hartford connecticut is known as tobacco valley and the fields and drying sheds are visible to travelers on the road to and from bradley field the major connecticut airport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tobacco grown here is known as shade tobacco and is used as outer wrappers for some of the world's finest cigars
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early connecticut colonists acquired from the native americans the habit of smoking tobacco in pipes and began cultivating the plant commercially even though the puritans referred to it as the evil weed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the plant was outlawed in connecticut in 1650 but in the 1800s as cigar smoking began to be popular tobacco farming became a major industry employing farmers laborers local youths southern african americans and migrant workers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: working conditions varied from pleasant summer work for students to backbreaking exploitation of migrants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each tobacco plant yields only 18 leaves useful as cigar wrappers and each leaf requires a great deal of individual manual attention after harvesting some of which must be carried out in the drying sheds where the temperature exceeds 100 degrees fahrenheit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1921 connecticut tobacco production peaked at 31000 acres 125 km² under cultivation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rise of cigarette smoking and the decline of cigar smoking has caused a corresponding decline in the demand for shade tobacco reaching a minimum in 1992 of 2000 acres 8 km² under cultivation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since then however cigar smoking has become more popular again and in 1997 tobacco farming had risen to 4000 acres 16 km²
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the industry has weathered some major catastrophes including a devastating hailstorm in 1929 and an epidemic of brown spot fungus in 2000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: perhaps the most strongly flavored of all tobaccos is the perique from saint james parish louisiana
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the acadians made their way into this region in 1776 the choctaw and chickasaw tribes were cultivating a variety of tobacco with a distinctive flavor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a farmer called pierre chenet is credited with first turning this local tobacco into the perique in 1824 through the technique of pressure fermentation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tobacco plants are manually kept suckerless and pruned to exactly 12 leaves through their early growth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in late june when the leaves are a dark rich green and the plants are 24-30 inches 600 to 750 mm tall the whole plant is harvested in the late evening and hung to dry in a sideless curing barn
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once the leaves have partially dried but while still supple usually less than 2 weeks in the barn any remaining dirt is removed and the leaves are moistened with water and stemmed by hand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the leaves are then rolled into torquettes of approximately 1 pound 450 g and packed into hickory whiskey barrels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tobacco is then kept under pressure using oak blocks and massive screw jacks forcing nearly all the air out of the still moist leaves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: approximately once a month the pressure is released and each of the torquettes is worked by hand to permit a little air back into the tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after a year of this treatment the perique is ready for consumption although it may be kept fresh under pressure for many years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: extended exposure to air degrades the particular character of the perique
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the finished tobacco is dark brown nearly black very moist with a fruity slightly vinegary aroma
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: considered the truffle of pipe tobaccos the perique is used as a component of many blended pipe tobaccos but is too strong to be smoked pure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at one time the freshly moist perique was also chewed but none is now sold for this purpose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: less than 16 acres 65000 m² of this crop remain in cultivation most by a single farmer called percy martin in grande pointe louisiana
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for reasons unknown the particular flavor and character of the perique can only be acquired on a small triangle of saint james parish less than 3 by 10 miles 5 by 16 km
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although at its peak saint james parish was producing around 20 tons of the perique a year output is now merely a few barrelsful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while traditionally a pipe tobacco and still available from some specialist tobacconists the perique may now also be found in the perique cigarettes of santa fe natural tobacco co in an approximately 1 part to 5 blend with lighter tobaccos
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a similar tobacco based on pressure fermented kentucky tobacco is available by the name acadian green river perique
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: snuff is a generic term for fine ground smokeless tobacco products
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally the term referred only to dry snuff a fine tan dust popular mainly in the eighteenth century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is often called scotch snuff a folk etymology derivation of the scorching process used to dry the cured tobacco by the factory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: european dry snuff is intended to be sniffed up the nose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: snuff is not snorted due to the fact that snuff shouldn't get past the nose i.e into sinuses throat or lungs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: european snuff comes in several varieties plain toast fine ground very dry medicated menthol camphor eucalyptus etc scented and schmalzler a german variety the major brand names of european snuff are bernards germany fribourg & treyer uk gawith uk gawith hoggarth uk hedges uk lotzbeck germany mcchrystal's uk poschl germany and wilsons of sharrow uk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: snuff has even been found to be beneficial in some cases of hay fever due to the fact that the snuff may prevent allergens from getting to the mucus membrane within the nose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: american snuff is much stronger and is intended to be dipped
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it comes in two varieties sweet and salty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: until the early 20th century snuff dipping was popular in the united states among rural people who would often use sweet barkless twigs to apply it to their gums
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: popular brands are tube rose and navy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the second and more popular in north america variety of snuff is moist snuff or dipping tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this practice is known as dipping in the southern states taking a dip of moist snuff is called putting a rub in the moist snuff in the mouth is known as a rub this is occasionally referred to as snoose in new england and the midwest and is derived from the scandinavian word for snuff snus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like the word the origins of moist snuff are scandinavian and the oldest american brands indicate that by their names
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: american moist snuff is made from dark fire cured tobacco that is ground sweetened and aged by the factory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prominent north american brands are copenhagen skoal timber wolf chisholm grizzly and kodiak
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: american moist snuff tends to be dipped
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some modern smokeless tobacco brands such as kodiak have an aggressive nicotine delivery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is accomplished with a higher dose of nicotine than cigarettes a high ph level which helps nicotine enter the blood stream faster and a high portion of unprotonated free base nicotine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has been suggested by the economist magazine that the ban on smoking tobacco indoors in some areas such as britain and new york city may lead to a resurgence in the popularity of snuff as an alternative to tobacco smoking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the large scale closure of british mines in the 1980s deprived the snuff industry of its major market since snuff became unfashionable miners took snuff underground instead of smoking to avoid lethal explosions and fires sales at britain's largest snuff retailer have reportedly been rising at about 5% per year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chewing is one of the oldest ways of consuming tobacco leaves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: native americans in both north and south america chewed the leaves of the plant frequently mixed with lime
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern chewing tobacco is produced in three forms twist plug and scrap
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few manufacturers in the united kingdom produce particularly strong twist tobacco meant for use in smoking pipes rather than chewing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these twists are not mixed with lime although they may be flavored with whisky rum cherry or other flavors common to pipe tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: twist is the oldest form
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one to three high quality leaves are braided and twisted into a rope while green and then are cured in the same manner as other tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally devised by sailors due to fire hazards of smoking at sea and until recently this was done by farmers for their personal consumption in addition to other tobacco intended for sale
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern twist is occasionally lightly sweetened
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is still sold commercially but rarely seen outside of appalachia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: popular brands are mammoth cave moore's red leaf and cumberland gap
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: users cut a piece off the twist and chew it expectorating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: plug chewing tobacco is made by pressing together cured tobacco leaves in a sweet often molasses based syrup
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally this was done by hand but since the second half of the 19th century leaves were pressed between large tin sheets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the resulting sheet of tobacco is cut into plugs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like twist consumers sometimes cut but more often bite off a piece of the plug to chew
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: major brands are days o work and cannonball
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: scrap or looseleaf chewing tobacco was originally the excess of plug manufacturing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is sweetened like plug tobacco but sold loose in bags rather than a plug
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: looseleaf is by far the most popular form of chewing tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: popular brands are red man beechnut mail pouch and southern pride
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: looseleaf chewing tobacco can also be dipped
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the peak of popularity of chewing tobacco in the western united states in the late 19th century spittoons were a common device for users to spit into
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: swedish snus is different in that it is made from steam cured tobacco rather than fire cured and its health effects are markedly different with epidemiological studies showing dramatically lower rates of cancer and other tobacco related health problems than cigarettes american chewing tobacco indian gutka or african varieties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prominent swedish brands are swedish match ettan and tre ankare
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the scandinavian countries moist snuff comes either in loose powder form to be pressed into a small ball or ovoid either by hand or with the use of a special tool
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is sometimes packaged in small bags suitable for placing inside the upper lip called "portion snuff
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states the skoal brand of moist snuff distributes a similar product packed with standard american moist snuff often flavored with fruits or liquors these small bags are called skoal pouches these small bags keep the loose tobacco from becoming lodged between the user's teeth they also generate less spittle when in contact with mucous membranes inside the mouth which extends the usage time of the tobacco product.since it is not smoked snuff in general generates less of the nitrosamines and other carcinogens in the tar that forms from the partially anaerobic reactions in the smoldering smoked tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the steam curing of snus rather than fire curing or flue curing of other smokeless tobaccos has been demonstrated to generate even fewer of such compounds than other varieties of snuff 2.8 parts per mil for ettan brand compared to as high as 127.9 parts per mil in american brands according to a study by the state of massachusetts health department
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is hypothesized that the widespread use of snus by swedish men estimated at 30% of swedish men possibly because it is much cheaper than cigarettes displacing tobacco smoking and other varieties of snuff is responsible for the incidence of tobacco related mortality in men being significantly lower in sweden than any other european country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast since women are much less likely to use snus their rate of tobacco related deaths in sweden is similar to that in other european countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: snus is clearly less harmful than other tobacco products according to kenneth warner director of the university of michigan tobacco research network :"the swedish government has studied this stuff to death and to date there is no compelling evidence that it has any adverse health consequences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whatever they eventually find out it is dramatically less dangerous than smoking public health researchers maintain that nevertheless even the low nitrosamine levels in snus cannot be completely risk free but snus proponents maintain that inasmuch as snus is used as a substitute for smoking or a means to quit smoking the net overall effect is positive similar to the effect of nicotine patches for instance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: snus is banned in the european union countries outside of sweden regular snus not portion is allowed in denmark and snus is also becoming a regular among norwegians as cigarettes are seen by norwegian popular culture as untrendy and much more unhealthy than snus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although this is officially for health reasons it is widely regarded in fact as being for economic reasons since other smokeless tobacco products mainly from india associated with much greater risk to health are sold too
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although it lacks the carcinogenicity of high levels of nitrosamines however any harmful effects of nicotine will still be seen with snus usage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: current research concentrates on nicotine's effect on the circulatory system and on the pancreas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on june 11 2006 reynolds tobacco announced that it would be test marketing camel brand snus in portland oregon and austin texas by the end of the month
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the product would be manufactured in sweden in conjunction with british american tobacco manufacturers of bat snus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gutka is a tobacco product manufactured and used mainly in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it contains sweeteners food coloring and paan flavorings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is used by constantly chewing without swallowing the juices and then spitting the juices out once the mouth is full of the liquid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this results in the walls of most public buildings to be covered in red stains called pichkari especially in areas where males from lower income levels congregate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: creamy snuff is a tobacco paste consisting of tobacco clove oil glycerin spearmint menthol and camphor and sold in a toothpaste tube
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is marketed mainly to women in india and is known by the brand names ipco made by asha industries denobac tona ganesh
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to the us nih sponsored 2002 smokeless tobacco fact sheet it is marketed as a dentifrice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the same factsheet also mentions that it is often used to clean teeth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the manufacturer recommends letting the paste linger in the mouth before rinsing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tobacco water is a traditional organic insecticide used in domestic gardening
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tobacco dust can be used similarly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is produced by boiling strong tobacco in water or by steeping the tobacco in water for a longer period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when cooled the mixture can be applied as a spray or painted on to the leaves of garden plants where it will prove deadly to insects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: basque angulero fishermen kill immature eels elvers in an infusion of tobacco leaves before parboiling them in salty water for transportation to market as angulas a seasonal delicacy.-->

lines.value: the evolution of homo sapiens is characterized by a number of important trends how these trends are related in what ways they have been adaptive and what their role is in the evolution of complex social organization and culture are matters of ongoing debate among physical anthropologists

lines.value: although body size is highly heritable it is also significantly influenced by environmental and cultural factors such as diet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mean height of an american adult female is 162 cm 64 in and the mean weight is 62 kg 137 lb
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: males are typically larger 175 cm 69 in and 78 kilograms 172 lb
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: humans vary substantially around these means and the means themselves have varied depending on locality and historical factors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: human children typically weighing 3-4 kilograms 6-9 pounds and 50-60 centimetres 20-24 inches in height are born after a nine month gestation period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: helpless at birth they continue to grow for some years typically reaching sexual maturity at around 12 15 years of age
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: boys continue growing for some time after this often only reaching their maximum height around the age of 18.human life expectancy at birth is approaching 80 years in wealthy nations with the assistance of science and technology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the number of centenarians in the world was estimated at about 50000 in 2003

lines.value: the maximum human life span is thought to be about 120 years
