lines.value: within the last few decades humans have been able to temporarily inhabit antarctica the ocean depths and outer space although permanent habitation of these three environments is not yet possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: humans with a population of about six billion are one of the most numerous mammals on earth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most humans 61% live in the asian region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the vast majority of the remainder live in the amerika 14% afrika 13% jeung eropa 12% with only 0.3% in australia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see list of countries by population and list of countries by population density
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: being primates humans original life style is hunting gathering which is adapted to the savannah where they evolved
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other human life styles are nomadism often linked to animal herding and permanent settlements made possible by the development of agriculture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: humans have a great capacity for altering their habitats by various methods such as agriculture irrigation urban planning and construction and activities accessory to those such as transportation and manufacturing goods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: permanent human settlements are dependent on proximity to water and depending on the lifestyle other natural resources such as fertile land for growing crops and grazing livestock or seasonally by populations of prey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the advent of large scale trade and transportation infrastructure immediate proximity to these resources has become less necessary and in many places these factors are no longer the driving force behind growth and decline of population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a sizable minority around 2.5 of a total of 6.3 billion people live in urban surroundings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: urbanisation is expected to rise drastically during the 21st century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: problems for humans in cities include various forms of pollution crime and poverty especially in inner city and suburban slums
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: humans living on antarctica under the ocean or in space are part of scientific military or industrial expeditions and habitation of these environments is temporary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: life in space has thus far been temporary living with up to ten humans in space at a given time seven on the space shuttle three on mir and currently around three in the international space station
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is a direct result of humans vulnerability to ionizing radiation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prior to 1961 all humans were restricted to the earth yuri gagarin was the first human to travel into space
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at various periods between 1969 and 1974 up to two humans spent varying amounts of time on the moon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as of yet residencies or human explorations on other planets have not come to be
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: humans often consider themselves to be the dominant species on earth and the most advanced in intelligence and ability to manage their environment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this belief is especially strong in western culture and is based in part on the biblical creation story in which adam is explicitly given dominion over the earth and all of its creatures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: biologists and scientists in general though do not consider dominant to be a useful term because the adaptive value of any trait or complex of traits depends on the niche and is highly mutable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from a scientific standpoint homo sapiens certainly is among the most generalized species on earth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: smaller and simpler animals such as bacteria and insects greatly surpass humans in population size and diversity of species but few single species occupy as many diverse environments as humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many other species for example are adapted to specific environments whereas humans rely on the use of fire and on tools such as clothing and manufactured shelter which are themselves often produced and used through complex social interactions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various attempts have been made to identify a single behavioral characteristic that distinguishes humans from all other animals e.g the ability to make and use tools building shelter weaving fabrics for clothing the ability to alter the environment language and the development of complex social relationships and structures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: considered in isolation however these differences are not absolute as ethologists have recorded such behaviors in many species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: apes and even birds for example are known to fish for insects using blades of grass or twigs and even to shape the tools for that purpose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for these reasons the idea that making and using tools is a defining characteristic of humans is often considered outdated though of course no other animal uses tools to the same degree or with the same flexibility as homo sapiens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly other animals often have methods of communication but the degree to which humans create and use complex grammar and abstract concepts in language has not been seen in any other species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chomskian linguistics holds that a distinguishing feature of humans is that they are the only extant species with a language instinct a genetic predisposition that produces a brain mechanism whose function is to acquire a language by observing those around us
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dolphins may also have this trait as they show dialect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some anthropologists think that these readily observable characteristics tool-making and language are based on less easily observable mental processes that might be unique among humans the ability to think symbolically
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that is humans can think abstractly about concepts and ideas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they can question use logic understand mathematical concepts and so on in ways greater than other animals are known to do although several species have demonstrated some abilities in these areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in any case the idea that these abilities distinguish humans from other species is the basis of the name homo sapiens sometimes translated as man the thinker
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it should be noted however that the extinct species of the homo genus e.g homo neanderthalensis homo erectus were also adept tool makers and there is some evidence that they may have had linguistic skills
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while humans have all these characteristics from the biological viewpoint the question what single characteristic distinguishes humans from all other animals is an odd one it is not a question that is usually asked of cats dolphins or song sparrows
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finding other species that shape tools or can use sign language may shed light on human evolution but it doesn't erase the differences or similarities between humans and other species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tes pearson's chi kuadrat x<sup>2</sup> salah sahiji variasi tina tes chi kuadrat - procedure statistik nu hasilna di evaluasi dumasar kana sebaran chi kuadrat
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tes ieu mimiti dipaluruh ku karl pearson
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it tests a null hypothesis that the relative frequencies of occurrence of observed events follow a specified frequency distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the events are assumed to be independent and have the same distribution and the outcomes of each event must be mutually exclusive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a simple example is the hypothesis that an ordinary six sided die is fair i.e all six outcomes occur equally often
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson's chi square is the original and most widely used chi square test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chi square is calculated by finding the difference between each observed and theoretical frequency for each possible outcome squaring them dividing each by the theoretical frequency and taking the sum of the results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the number of degrees of freedom is equal to the number of possible outcomes minus 1 : = the number of possible outcomes of each event
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson's chi square is used to assess two types of comparison tests of goodness of fit and tests of independence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a test of goodness of fit establishes whether or not an observed frequency distribution differs from a theoretical distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a test of independence assesses whether paired observations on two variables expressed in a contingency table are independent of each other - for example whether people from different regions differ in the frequency with which they report that they support a political candidate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a chi square probability of 0.05 or less is commonly interpreted by applied workers as justification for rejecting the null hypothesis that the row variable is unrelated that is only randomly related to the column variable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the alternate hypothesis is not rejected when the variables have an associated relationship
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example to test the hypothesis that a random sample of 100 people has been drawn from a population in which men and women are equal in frequency the observed number of men and women would be compared to the theoretical frequencies of 50 men and 50 women
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if there were 45 men in the sample and 55 women then if the null hypothesis is true i.e men and women are chosen with equal probability in the sample the test statistic will be drawn from a chi square distribution with one degree of freedom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though one might expect two degrees of freedom one each for the men and women we must take into account that the total number of men and women is constrained 100 and thus there is only one degree of freedom 2 − 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: alternatively if the male count is known the female count is determined and vice versa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: consultation of the chi square distribution for 1 degree of freedom shows that the probability of observing this difference or a more extreme difference than this if men and women are equally numerous in the population is approximately 0.3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this probability is higher than conventional criteria for statistical significance so normally we would not reject the null hypothesis that the number of men in the population is the same as the number of women
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the approximation to the chi square distribution breaks down if expected frequencies are too low
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it will normally be acceptable so long as no more than 10% of the events have expected frequencies below 5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: where there is only 1 degree of freedom the approximation is not reliable if expected frequencies are below 10
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this case a better approximation can be had by reducing the absolute value of each difference between observed and expected frequencies by 0.5 before squaring this is called yates correction for continuity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in cases where the expected value e is found to be small indicating either a small underlying population probability or a small number of observations the normal approximation of the multinomial distribution can fail and in such cases it is found to be more appropriate to use the g test a likelihood ratio based test statistic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: where the total sample size is small it is necessary to use an appropriate exact test typically either the binomial test or for contingency tables fisher's exact test but note that this test assumes fixed and known marginal totals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the null distribution of the pearson statistic with j rows and k columns is approximated by the chi square distribution with k − 1)(j − 1 degrees of freedom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this approximation arises as the true distribution under the null hypothesis if the expected value is given by a multinomial distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for large sample sizes the central limit theorem says this distribution tends toward a certain multivariate normal distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the special case where there are only two cells in the table the expected values follow a binomial distribution let o 1 be the number of observations from the sample that are in the first cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the pearson test statistic can be expressed as so as consistent with the meaning of the chi square distribution we are measuring how probable the observed number of standard deviations away from the mean is under the gaussian approximation which is a good approximation for large n
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the chi square distribution is then integrated on the right of the statistic value to obtain the probability that this result or worse were observed given the model
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similar arguments as above lead to the desired result
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: todo details each cell except the final one whose value is completely determined by the others is treated as an independent binomial variable and their contributions are summed and each contributes one degree of freedom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a more complicated but more widely used form of pearson's chi square test arises in the case where the null hypothesis of interest includes unknown parameters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance we may wish to test whether some data follows a normal distribution but without specifying a mean or variance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this situation the unknown parameters need to be estimated by the data typically by maximum likelihood estimation and these estimates are then used to calculate the expected values in the pearson statistic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is commonly stated that the degrees of freedom for the chi square distribution of the statistic are then k − 1 − r where r is the number of unknown parameters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this result is valid when the original data was multinomial and hence the estimated parameters are efficient for minimizing the chi square statistic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more generally however when maximum likelihood estimation does not coincide with minimum chi square estimation the distribution will lie somewhere between a chi square distribution with k − 1 − r and k − 1 degrees of freedom see for instance chernoff and lehmann 1954
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: * chernoff h lehmann el the use of maximum likelihood estimates in tests for goodness of fit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the formal study of ethics in a serious and analytical sense began with the early greeks and later romans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: important greek ethicists include the sophists and socrates plato and aristotle who developed ethical naturalism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the study of ethics was developed further by epicurus and the epicurean movement and by zeno and the stoics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although not developed in a formal and analytical sense the subject of ethics was of great concern to the hindu people in ancient india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the first time in world history they described the highest ethical standards called absolute ethics by albert schweitzer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: millennia later the society of friends or the quakers reached as high as the jinas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also ethics in religion in europe the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the era of maimonides thomas aquinas and others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was in those days that the debate between ethics based on natural law and divine law gained a new importance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern western philosophy began with the work of greats such as thomas hobbes david hume and immanuel kant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their work was followed up by the utilitarians jeremy bentham and john stuart mill
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arthur schopenhauer must be mentioned here because of his preisschrift uber die grundlage der moral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was the first european philosopher to start out from the ethical achievements of ancient india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the study of analytic ethics went on with g e moore and w d ross followed by the emotivists c l stevenson and a j ayer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: existentialism was developed by writers such as jean paul sartre
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some modern philosophers who have done serious philosophical writing on ethics include john rawls elliot n dorff jurgen habermas christine korsgaard and charles hartshorne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are at least five well recognized ways to approach this subject
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: assumptions about ethical underpinnings of human behaviour are reflected in every social science including economics because of its role in the distribution of scarce resources in political science because of its role in allocating power in sociology because of its roots in the dynamics of groups in law because of its role in codifying ethical constructs like mercy and punishment in criminology because of its role in rewarding ethical behaviour and discouraging unethical behaviour in psychology because of its role in defining understanding and treating unethical behaviour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however hard science needs ethics too
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also important in biology as bioethics and ecology as environmental ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as these fields become more complex and deal with more situations ethics too tends to become complex
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but schopenhauer stated that the first ethical principle was extremely simple and convincing neminem laede imo omnes quantum potes juva do no harm to anyone but give a helping hand to as many people as you can
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many questions in ethics are deeply concerned with the claiming of rights especially when authority is present
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the potential to invoke authority and force of arms lies heavy over all ethical decisions in all but an anarchy when balances between rights are considered especially in public policy ethics becomes politics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when religious concepts are considered to dominate over human conceptions of right and wrong ethics are often presumed to derive from a moral code usually divinely inspired or revealed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see ethics in religion below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: non philosophers may wish to review the article simple view of ethics and morals which deals with ethics in much simpler language
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that article focuses on how people who make decisions see things while this one focuses on how people who study decisions see things
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the two are typically not the same as much more doubt and deliberation is involved in coming to agreement about principles that are to apply for a long time for a whole society or for mankind and those who make decisions see things more simply
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in analytic philosophy ethics is traditionally divided into three fields metaethics normative ethics including value theory and the theory of conduct and applied ethics which is seen to be derived top down from normative and thus meta ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metaethics is the investigation of the nature of ethical statements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it involves such questions as are ethical claims truth apt i.e capable of being true or false or are they for example expressions of emotion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if they are truth apt are they ever true
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if they are ever true what is the nature of the facts that they express
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and are they ever true absolutely or always only relative to some individual society or culture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see moral relativism cultural relativism metaethics is one of the most important fields in philosophy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metaethics studies the nature of ethical sentences and attitudes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this includes such questions as what good and right mean whether and how we know what is right and good whether moral values are objective and how ethical attitudes motivate us
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often this is derived from some list of moral absolutes e.g a religious moral code whether explicit or not
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some would view aesthetics as itself a form of meta ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metaethics also investigates where our ethical principles come from and what they mean
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: are they merely social inventions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: do they involve more than expressions of our individual emotions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metaethical answers to these questions focus on the issues of universal truths the will of god the role of reason in ethical judgments and the meaning of ethical terms themselves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: normative ethics bridges the gap between metaethics and applied ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is the attempt to arrive at practical moral standards that tell us right from wrong and how to live moral lives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this may involve articulating the good habits that we should acquire the duties that we should follow or the consequences of our behavior on others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: applied ethics applies normative ethics to specific controversial issues
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of these ethical problems bear directly on public policy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the following would be questions of applied ethics is getting an abortion ever moral is euthanasia ever moral what are the ethical underpinnings of affirmative action policies do animals have rights without these questions there is no clear fulcrum on which to balance law politics and practice of arbitration in fact no common assumptions of all participants so the ability to formulate the questions are prior to rights balancing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but not all questions studied in applied ethics concern public policy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example is lying always wrong
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if not when is it permissible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ability to make these ethical judgements is prior to any etiquette
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several sub branches of applied ethics examining the ethical problems of different professions such as business ethics medical ethics engineering ethics and legal ethics while technology assessment and environmental assessment study the effects and implications of new technologies or projects on nature and society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each branch to characterize common issues and problems that arise in the ethical codes of the professions and define their common responsibility to the public e.g to preserve its natural capital or to obey some social expectations of honest dealings and disclosure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethics has been applied to family structure sexuality and how society views the roles of individuals leading to several distinct and unrelated fields of applied ethics including feminism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethics has been applied to war leading to the fields of pacifism and nonviolence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethics has been applied to analyze human use of earth's limited resources
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has led to the study of environmental ethics and social ecology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a growing trend has been to combine the study of both ecology and economics to help provide a basis for sustainable decisions on environmental use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has led to the theories of ecological footprint and bioregional autonomy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: political and social movements based on such ideas include eco feminism eco anarchism deep ecology the green movement and ideas about their possible integration into gaia philosophy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethics has been applied to criminology leading to the field of criminal justice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several sub branches of applied ethics examining the ethical problems of different professions such as business ethics medical ethics engineering ethics and legal ethics while technology assessment and environmental assessment study the effects and implications of new technologies or projects on nature and society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each branch characterizes common issues and problems that may arise and define their common responsibility to the public e.g to preserve its natural capital or to obey some social expectations of honest dealings and disclosure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by far the most common way to approach applied ethics is by resolving individual cases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is not coincidentally also the way business and law tend to be taught
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: casuistry is one such application of case based reasoning to applied ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: almost all american states have tried to discourage dishonest practices by their public employees and elected officials by establishing an ethics commission for their state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bernard crick in 1982 offered a more socially centered view that politics was the only applied ethics that it was how cases were really resolved and that political virtues were in fact necessary in all matters where human morality and interests were destined to clash
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this and other views of modern universals is dealt with below under global ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the lines of distinction between metaethics normative ethics and applied ethics are often blurry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the issue of abortion is an applied ethical topic since it involves a specific type of controversial behavior
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but it also depends on more general normative principles such as the right of self rule and the right to life which are litmus tests for determining the morality of that procedure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the issue also rests on metaethical issues such as where do rights come from and what kind of beings have rights
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some philosophers rely on descriptive ethics and choices made and unchallenged by a society or culture to derive categories which typically vary by context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this leads to situational ethics and situated ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these philosophers often view aesthetics and etiquette and arbitration as more fundamental percolating bottom up to imply rather than explicitly state theories of value or of conduct
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in these views ethics is not derived from a top down a priori philosophy many would reject that word but rather is strictly derived from observations of actual choices made in practice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the descriptive view of ethics is modern and in many ways more empirical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but because the above are dealt with more deeply in their own articles the rest of this article will focus on the formal academic categories which are derived from classical greek philosophy especially aristotle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: first we need to define an ethical sentence also called a normative statement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an ethical sentence is one that is used to make either a positive or a negative moral evaluation of something
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethical sentences use words such as good bad right wrong moral immoral and so on
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here are some examples
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the whole assumption of the field of ethics is that consistent description consistent deliberation and consistent and fair application of authority is possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the more case based views seem to suggest that a great deal of judgement is required and that for instance one could never train a robot to do ethics as it requires empathy and wisdom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however one might be able to teach an artificial intelligence with empathy and wisdom to do ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: is each case unique
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: possibly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the view that ethics is innate and tied to a personal moral core or aesthetic is harder to relate to the formal categories above other than as a meta ethics in itself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is considered by some ethicists to be just a variant of mysticism or narcissism permitting those who avow aesthetic choices as being above ethics to justify anything
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the term ethics is actually derived from the ancient greek ethos meaning moral character
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mores from which morality is derived meant social rules or etiquette or inhibitions from the society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in modern times these meanings are often somewhat reversed with ethics being the external science and morals referring to one's inmost character or choices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but it is significant that the origins of the words reflect the tension between an inner driven and an outer driven view of what makes moral choices consistent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see ethics in religion and ethics in the bible

lines.value: one of the major areas where ethics and ethicists practice is in the field of medicine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: example issues are euthanasia medical experiments genetic modification of organisms and humans vaccine trials triage and others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the 1960s there was increased interest in moral reasoning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: psychologists such as lawrence kohlberg and carol gilligan developed theories which are based on the idea that moral behaviour is made possible by moral reasoning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their theories subdivided moral reasoning into so called stages which refer to the set of principles or methods that a person uses for ethical judgement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first and most famous theory of this type was kohlberg's theory of moral development another group of influential psychological theories with ethical implications is the humanistic psychology movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the most famous humanistic theories is abraham maslow's hierarchy of needs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: maslow argued that the highest human need is self actualization which can be described as fulfilling one's potential and trying to fix what is wrong in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: carl rogers's work was based on similar assumptions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he thought that in order to be a fully functioning person one has to be creative and accept one's own feelings and needs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also emphasized the value of self actualization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a similar theory was proposed by fritz perls who assumed that taking responsibility of one's own life is an important value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a third group of psychological theories that have implications for the nature of ethics are based on evolutionary psychology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these theories are based on the assumption that the behaviour that ethics prescribe can sometimes be seen as an evolutionary adaptation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance altruism towards members of one's own family promotes one's inclusive fitness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often such efforts take legal or political form before they are understood as works of normative ethics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the un declaration of universal human rights of 1948 and the global green charter of 2001 are two such examples

lines.value: however as war and the development of weapon technology continues it seems clear that no non violent means of dispute resolution is accepted by all

lines.value: the need to redefine and align politics away from ideology and towards dispute resolution was a motive for bernard crick's list of political virtues

lines.value: philosophers have developed a number of competing systems to explain how to choose what is best for both the individual and for society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: no one system has gained universal assent

lines.value: india is referred to as the largest democracy in the world by virtue of the fact that it has the largest electing population among democratic countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the country has a federal form of government and a bicameral parliament operating under a westminster style parliamentary system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has three branches of governance the legislature executive and judiciary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the president is the head of state though he has a largely ceremonial role to play
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he is also the supreme commander of india's armed forces
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the president is elected indirectly by an electoral college for five year terms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: presidential assent is needed for a bill or ordinance passed by the parliament to come into force
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the prime minister is the de facto head of government and has most executive powers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he or she is appointed by the president with the requirement that he or she enjoy the support of the party or coalition having more than 50% seats in the lower house
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the union council of ministers headed by the prime minister aids and advises the president on governance matters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the legislature of india is the bicameral parliament which consists of the upper house called the rajya sabha council of states and the lower house called the lok sabha house of people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 245-member rajya sabha is chosen indirectly through the state legislative assemblies and has a staggered six year term
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each state sends members to the rajya sabha in a proportion of its population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 545-member lok sabha is directly elected some seats are reserved for caste based system by popular vote for a five year term except two nominated anglo indian members and is the determinative constituent of political power and government formation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: universal adulthood suffrage is guaranteed by the constitution for citizens above 18 years of age
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the executive arm consists of the president vice president and the council of ministers the cabinet being its executive committee headed by the prime minister
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: any minister holding a portfolio must be a member of either house of parliament
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the indian parliamentary system the executive is subordinate to the legislature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's independent judiciary consists of the supreme court headed by the chief justice of india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the supreme court has both original jurisdiction over disputes between states and the centre and appellate jurisdiction over the eighteen high courts of india and additionally the power to declare union and state laws null and void if in conflict with the constitution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for most of its independent history india has been ruled by the indian national congress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the party enjoyed a parliamentary majority barring two brief periods during the 1970s and late 1980s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this rule was interrupted between 1977 to 1980 when the janata party coalition won the election owing to public discontent with the emergency declared by the then prime minister indira gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the janata dal won elections in 1989 but its government managed to hold on to power for only two years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: between 1996 and 1998 there was a period of political flux with the government being formed first by the right of centre nationalist bharatiya janata party bjp followed by a left leaning united front coalition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1998 the bjp formed the national democratic alliance nda with smaller regional parties and became the first non congress and coalition government to complete a full five year term
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 2004 indian elections saw the left leaning congress party winning the largest number of seats to form a government by leading the united progressive alliance and supported by communist parties and those opposed to the bjp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since independence india has maintained cordial relationships with most nations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it took a lead in the 1950s in advocating the independence of european colonies in africa and asia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the cold war india tried to maintain its neutrality and was one of the founding members of the non aligned movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the sino indian war and the indo pakistani war of 1965 india's relationship with the soviet union warmed at the expense of ties with the united states and continued to remain so until the end of the cold war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india has consistently refused to sign the ctbt and the npt to maintain sovereignty over its nuclear program despite criticism and military sanctions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recent overtures by the indian government have strengthened india's relations with united states china and pakistan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the economic sphere india has close relationships with other developing nations of south america asia and africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in recent years india has played an influential role in the saarc
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india has been a long time supporter of the united nations with over 55000 indian military and police personnel having served in 35 un peace keeping operations over four continents
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the 1990s india has been considered a great or major power on the global stage meaning it has considerable influence on international affairs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: administratively india is divided into twenty eight states which are further subdivided into districts and seven union territories or territories owned by the central government
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all states and the union territories of delhi and pondicherry have elected governments
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the remaining five union territories have centrally appointed administrators
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the states and territories are further divided into 602 districts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also districts of india list of indian districts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the territory of india constitutes a major portion of the indian subcontinent situated on the indian plate the northerly portion of the indo australian plate in southern asia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's northern and northeastern states are partially situated in the himalayan mountain range
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rest of northern central and eastern india consists of the fertile indo gangetic plain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the west bordering southeast pakistan lies the thar desert
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the southern indian peninsula is almost entirely composed of the deccan plateau which is flanked by two hilly coastal ranges the western ghats and eastern ghats
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is home to several major rivers including the ganga brahmaputra yamuna godavari kaveri narmada and krishna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india has three archipelagos - lakshadweep off the southwest coast the andaman and nicobar islands volcanic island chain to the southeast and the sunderbans in the gangetic delta in west bengal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: climate in india varies from tropical in the south to more temperate in the himalayan north with elevated regions in the north receiving sustained snowfall in winters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's climate is strongly influenced by the himalayas and the thar desert
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the himalayas along with the hindu kush mountains in pakistan provide a barrier to the cold winds from central asia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this keeps most of the indian subcontinent warmer than most locations in similar latitudes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the thar desert is responsible for attracting the moisture laden southwest monsoon winds that provide most of india's rainfall between june and september
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the economy of india is the fourth largest in the world as measured by purchasing power parity ppp with a gdp of us $3.63 trillion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when measured in usd exchange rate terms it is the twelfth largest in the world with a gdp of $785.47 billion or rs 3534615 crore in 2005 as calculated by the world bank
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is the second fastest growing major economy in the world with a gdp growth rate of 9.1% as of the first quarter of 2006
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: wealth distribution in india a developing country is fairly uneven with the top 10% of income groups earning 33% of all income
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's per capita income ppp of us$ 3400 is ranked 122nd in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for most of its independent history india adhered to a quasi socialist approach with strict government control over private sector participation foreign trade and foreign direct investment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: starting from 1991 india has gradually opened up its markets through economic reforms by reducing government controls on foreign trade and investment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: privatisation of public owned industries and some sectors to private and foreign players has continued amid political debate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india has a labour force of 496.4 million of which 60% is employed in agriculture or agriculture related industries which contributes to only about 22% of the gdp 17% in mainstream industry and 23% in service industries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's agricultural produce includes rice wheat oilseed cotton jute tea sugarcane potatoes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: major industries include textiles chemicals food processing steel transportation equipment cement mining petroleum and machinery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's large english speaking middle class has contributed to the country's growth in business process outsourcing bpo
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is becoming a major base for us tech companies for future targeted research & development including the likes of google ibm and microsoft
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all this has helped the services sector to increase its share of the economy to approximately 50%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is also a major exporter of financial research and technology services
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's most important trading partners are the united states china uk singapore hong kong the united arab emirates switzerland and belgium
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is the second most populous country in the world with an estimated 1.1 billion people in 2006
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: language caste and religion are determinants of social and political organisation within its diverse population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although 81.5% of the people are hindus india is also home to the second largest population of muslims in the world 12.2% after indonesia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other religious groups include sikhs 2% christians 2.33% buddhists 0.76% jains 0.40% jews zoroastrians ahmadis and baha'is
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the national average literacy rate is 64.4%(with males 75.6% and females 54.2%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the state of kerala leads the country with a literacy rate of approximately 94%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unlike the usa uk and australian censuses the national census of india does not recognize racial or ethnic groups within india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's biggest metropolitan agglomerations are mumbai formerly bombay delhi kolkata formerly calcutta chennai formerly madras bangalore and hyderabad
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the national sex ratio is 933 females per 1000 males and median age is 24.66
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's birth rate is 22.32 births per 1000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the total fertility rate tfr for india is above the world average however the growth rate is showing signs of decrease in south india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is home to two major linguistic families indo aryan spoken by about 74% of the population and dravidian spoken by about 24%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other languages spoken in india come from the austro asiatic and tibeto burman linguistic families
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the indian constitution recognises 23 official languages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hindi and english are used by the union government of india for official purposes wherein hindi has a de jure priority
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sanskrit and tamil enjoy classical language status in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the number of dialects in india is as high as 1652
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india has a rich and unique cultural heritage and has managed to preserve its established traditions throughout history whilst absorbing customs traditions and ideas from both invaders and immigrants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many cultural practices languages customs and monuments are examples of this co mingling over centuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: famous monuments such as the taj mahal and other examples of islamic inspired architecture have been inherited from the mughal dynasty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are the result of a syncretic tradition that combined elements from all parts of the country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: indian music is represented in a wide variety of forms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the two main forms of classical music are carnatic from south india and hindustani from north india each of which has several popular sub classes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: popular forms of music also prevail the most notable being filmi music
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to this are the diverse traditions of folk music from different parts of the country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many classical dance forms exist including the bharatanatyam kathakali kathak kuchipudi odissi and manipuri
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they often have a narrative form and are usually infused with devotional and spiritual elements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the earliest literary traditions in india were mostly oral and were later transcribed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most of these are represented by sacred works like the vedas and the epics of the mahabharata and ramayana
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sangam literature from tamil nadu represents some of india's oldest traditions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there have been many notable modern indian writers both in indian languages and in english
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: millions of ancient handwritten manuscripts have been identified and classified
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's only nobel laureate in literature was the bengali writer rabindranath tagore
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is the third largest newspaper market in asia with an estimated circulation of at least 66 million copies daily in 2003
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the nation also produces the world's second largest number of motion pictures every year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most recognisable face is that of cinema production based in mumbai which produces mainly commercial hindi films often referred to as bollywood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are also strong cinema industries based on the bengali malayalam kannada tamil and telugu languages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: religious practices of various faiths are an integral part of everyday life in society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: religion in india is a very public affair with many practices imbued with pomp and vitality accompanying their underlying spiritual qualities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: education is highly regarded by members of every socio economic stratum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditional indian family values are highly respected and considered sacred although urban families have grown to prefer a nuclear family system owing to the socio economic constraints imposed by the traditional joint family system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cuisine of india is diverse as ingredients spices and cooking methods vary from region to region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rice and wheat are the staple foods in the country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the country is notable for its wide variety of vegetarian and non vegetarian
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spicy food and sweets are popular in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditional dress in india greatly varies across the regions in its colours and styles and depend on various factors including climate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: popular styles of dress include the traditional sari for women and the traditional dhoti for men
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india's national sport is field hockey although cricket is now the de facto national game
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some states particularly in the northeast football soccer is the most popular sport and is widely watched
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in recent times tennis has gained popularity in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chess is also gaining popularity with the rise of the number of recognised grandmasters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most commonly held view is that chess originated in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditional indigenous sports include kabaddi kho kho and gilli danda which are played in most parts of the country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: india is also known as a land of festivals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a melting pot of many religions india has a rich diversity of festivals many of which are celebrated irrespective of caste and creed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most widely known and popular celebrations include the hindu festivals of diwali holi pongal and dussehra and the muslim celebration of eid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a number of festivals are common to most parts of india however they may be called by different names in the various parts of the country or may be celebrated in a different fashion and style
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kulit teh diwangun ku dermis jeung epidermis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: di handapeun lapisan ieu aya hipodermis lapisan adiposa subkutan nu biasana mah teu digolongkeun salaku lapisan kulit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the outermost epidermis consists of stratified squamous epithelium with an underlying basement membrane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it contains no blood vessels and is nourished by diffusion from the dermis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the main type of cells which make up the epidermis are keratinocytes with melanocytes and langerhans cells also present
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the epidermis can be further subdivided into the following strata beginning with the outermost layer corneum lucidum granulosum spinosum basale
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cells are formed through mitosis at the innermost layers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they move up the strata changing shape and composition as they differentiate inducing expression of new types of keratin genes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they eventually reach the corneum and become sloughed off desquamation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this process is called keratinization and takes place within about 30 days
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dermis lies below the epidermis and contains a number of structures including blood vessels nerves hair follicles smooth muscle glands and lymphatic tissue

lines.value: it consists of loose connective tissue otherwise called areolar connective tissue collagen elastin and reticular fibres are present

lines.value: the main cell types are fibroblasts adipocytes fat storage and macrophages

lines.value: sebaceous glands are exocrine glands which produce sebum a mixture of lipids and waxy substances lubrication water proofing softening and antibactericidal actions are among the many functions of sebum

lines.value: the dermis can be split into the papillary and reticular layers

lines.value: the reticular layer is more dense and is continuous with the hypodermis

lines.value: the reticular layer is composed of irregularly arranged fibres and resists stretching

lines.value: the hypodermis is not part of the skin and lies below the dermis

lines.value: <!cotinine is a break down product of nicotine which remains in the blood for up to 48 hours and can be used as an indicator of a person's exposure to smoke
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in high doses nicotine will cause a depolarizing block of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor which is the reason for its toxicity and its effectiveness as an insecticide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition nicotine increases dopamine levels in the reward circuits of the brain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: studies have shown that smoking tobacco inhibits monoamine oxidase mao an enzyme responsible for breaking down monoaminergic neurotransmitters such as dopamine in the brain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is currently believed that nicotine by itself does not inhibit the production of monoamine oxidase mao but that other ingredients in inhaled tobacco smoke are believed to be responsible for this activity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this way it generates feelings of pleasure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this reaction is similar to that caused by cocaine and heroin and is another reason people keep smoking to sustain high dopamine levels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ld 50 of nicotine is 50 mg kg for rats and 3 mg kg for mice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 40 60 mg can be a lethal dosage for adult human beings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this dose makes it an extremely deadly poison
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is more toxic than many other alkaloids such as cocaine which has a lethal dose of 1000mg
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the carcinogenic properties of nicotine in standalone form separate from tobacco smoke have not been evaluated by the iarc and it has not been assigned to an official carcinogen group
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the currently available literature indicates that nicotine on its own does not promote the development of cancer in healthy tissue and has no mutagenic properties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its teratogenic properties have not yet been adequately researched and while the likelihood of birth defects caused by nicotine is believed to be very small or nonexistent nicotine replacement product manufacturers recommend consultation with a physician before using a nicotine patch or nicotine gum while pregnant or nursing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however nicotine and the increased acetylcholinic activity it causes have been shown to impede apoptosis which is one of the methods by which the body destroys unwanted cells programmed cell death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since apoptosis helps to remove mutated or damaged cells that may eventually become cancerous the inhibitory actions of nicotine creates a more favourable environment for cancer to develop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus nicotine plays an indirect role in carcinogenesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also important to note that its addictive properties are often the primary motivating factor for tobacco smoking contributing to the proliferation of cancer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at least one study has concluded that exposure to nicotine alone not simply as a component of cigarette smoke could be responsible for some of the neuropathological changes observed in infants dying from sudden infant death syndrome sids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has been noted that the majority of people diagnosed with schizophrenia smoke tobacco
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: estimates for the number of schizophrenics that smoke range from 75% to 90%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was recently argued that the increased level of smoking in schizophrenia may be due to a desire to self medicate with nicotine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more recent research has found the reverse that it is a risk factor without long term benefit used only for its short term effects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however research on nicotine as administered through a patch or gum is ongoing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the primary therapeutic use of nicotine is in treating nicotine dependence smoking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: controlled levels of nicotine are given to a patient through gums dermal patches or nasal sprays in an effort to wean them off of their dependence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recent studies have indicated that nicotine can be used to help adults suffering from autosomal dominant frontal lobe epilepsy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the same areas that cause seizures in that form of epilepsy are also responsible for processing nicotine in the brain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some research has also shown that nicotine can lessen symptoms of mild to moderate ulcerative colitis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nicotine and its metabolites are being researched for the treatment of a number of disorders including adhd parkinson's disease and alzheimer's disease.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: international astronomical union iau badan saintifik resmi keur tatangaran astronomi kakara wae ngadefinisikeun planet minangka banda angkasa nu minuhan sakabeh sarat ieu our solar system is considered to have eight planets under this definition mercury venus earth mars jupiter saturn uranus and neptune
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: three bodies which fulfil conditions i ii and iii but not iv and are also not natural satellites are now classified as dwarf planets ceres pluto and eris
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to date there have been more than two hundred planets discovered orbiting other stars
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this summary of the iau's position is based on two definitions released by the union
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although their stance on planets within our solar system has been formal adopted by the iau general assembly in 2006 the position on extrasolar planets remains only a working definition in place since 2003
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as such it is highly subject to change until it is formally adopted through due process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: before the adoption of the 2006 resolution there was no formally specified scientific definition of planet even for our own system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: without one the solar system had been traditionally seen as having various numbers of accepted planets over the years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it remains to be seen whether the new definition will become universally accepted both within the astronomical community where there has been opposition to the recent adoption and in the eyes of the greater public
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in near-universal practice in the western world the planets in the solar system are named after graeco roman gods as in europe it was the greeks who originally named them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the name planet comes from the greek term naavntns planetes meaning wanderer as ancient astronomers noted how certain lights moved across the sky in relation to the other stars
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these objects were believed to orbit the earth which was considered stationary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however due to the influence of the roman empire and later the catholic church in most countries in the west the planets are known by their roman or latin names rather than the original greek
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the romans who like the greeks were indo europeans shared with them a common pantheon under different names but lacked the rich narrative traditions that greek poetic culture had given their gods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the later period of the roman republic roman writers borrowed much of the greek narratives and applied them to their own pantheon to the point where they became virtually indistinguishable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the romans studied greek astronomy they gave the planets their own gods names
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greeks still use their original names for the planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in ancient times there were seven known planets they were in order from the supposedly central earth the moon called luna by the romans and selene by the greeks mercury called hermes by the greeks venus aphrodite the sun called sol by the romans helios by the greeks mars ares jupiter zeus and saturn kronos
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when subsequent planets were discovered in the 18th and 19th centuries the naming practice was retained uranus ouranos and neptune poseidon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some romans following a belief imported from mesopotamia into hellenistic egypt believed that the seven gods after whom the planets were named took hourly shifts in looking after affairs on earth in ptolemaic orbit order listed inwards
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a result
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a list of which god has charge of the first hour in each day came out as sun moon mars mercury jupiter venus saturn i.e the usual weekday name order
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sunday monday and saturday are straightforward translations of these roman names
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in english the other days were renamed after tiw woden thunor and frige anglo saxon gods considered similar or equivalent to mars mercury jupiter and venus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since earth was only generally accepted as a planet in the 17th century there is no tradition of naming it after a god
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however many of the romance languages including french italian spanish and portuguese which are descended from latin retain the old roman name of terra or some variation thereof again the greeks retain their original name yn ge or yi derived from gaia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the non romance languages use their own respective native words
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the germanic languages including english use a variation of an ancient germanic word ertho ground as can be seen in the english earth the german erde the dutch aarde and the scandinavian jorde
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the same is true for the sun and the moon though they are no longer considered planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some non european cultures use their own planetary naming systems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: china and the countries of eastern asia subject to chinese cultural influence such as japan korea and vietnam use a naming system based on the five chinese elements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: developments in astronomy meant the removal of the sun and the moon and the gradual addition of the currently accepted planetary members of the solar system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although a planet was commonly considered to be a large object orbiting the sun or later other stars there was no scientifically specified definition of planet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the acceptance of the heliocentric model over the geocentric model the solar system has been seen as having various numbers of accepted planets over the years based on culture and scientific consensus a similar scenario has occurred with pluto
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was first discovered beyond neptune in 1930 and was accepted by the international astronomical union as a planet after it was initially believed to be larger than the earth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however after further observation it was found that pluto was actually much smaller being less massive than the moon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after many similar new bodies were found beyond neptune during the 1990s and the early 2000s the iau decided to reclassify pluto as a dwarf planet in 2006
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of these objects was eris whose 2003 discovery was widely and preemtively reported in blogs journals and the mainstream media as the tenth planet although the iau never formally accepted the body
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many lobbied for eris to be included in the list of planets but after prolonged debate it joined ceres and pluto as a dwarf planet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also list of solar system bodies formerly considered planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the late 20th century with the discovery of large objects around other stars and also smaller objects within our own solar system the consensus began to break down
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there has been dispute over the precise size mass limits an object needed to qualify as a planet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there was particular dispute over whether round objects that existed in belts and large deuterium fusing objects should qualify
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2003 the iau working group on extrasolar planets made a position statement on the definition of a planet that incorporated a working definition however in 2006 the general assembly of the international astronomical union voted to pass a resolution that redefined planets within the solar system as :'a celestial body that is a in orbit around the sun b has sufficient mass for its self gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium nearly round shape and c has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit under this definition the solar system is considered to have eight planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bodies which fulfill the first two conditions but not the third such as pluto and eris are classified as dwarf planets providing they are not also natural satellites of other planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally an iau committee had proposed a definition that would have included a much larger number of planets because it did not include c as a criterion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: negotiations resulted in those bodies being reclassified as dwarf planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this definition is based in modern theories of planetary formation in which planetary embryos initially clear their orbital neighborhood of other smaller objects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a paper by steven soter describes it this way :'the end product of secondary disk accretion is a small number of relatively large bodies planets in either non intersecting or resonant orbits which prevent collisions between them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: asteroids and comets including kbos differ from planets in that they can collide with each other and with planets planetary discriminants defined in that paper very clearly separate the 8 iau recognized planets from all other small solar system objects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the aftermath of the iau's 2006 vote there has been some criticism of the new definition from astronomers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dispute centres around the belief that point c clearing its orbit should not have been listed and that those objects now categorised as dwarf planets should actually be part of a broader planetary definition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the next iau conference is not until 2009 when modifications could be made to the definition also possibly including extrasolar planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beyond the scientific community pluto has held a strong cultural significance for some of the public given its planetary status since 1930 in a similar way to ceres and its kin in the 1800s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more recently the discovery of eris widely publicised as the tenth planet was widely reported in the media as the tenth planet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the reclassification of all three objects as dwarf planets has attracted much media and public attention
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is not known with certainty how planets are formed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the prevailing theory is that they are formed from those remnants of a nebula that do not condense under gravity to form a protostar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead these remnants become a thin protoplanetary disk of dust and gas revolving around the protostar and begin to condense about local concentrations of mass within the disc known as planetesimals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these concentrations become ever more dense until they collapse inward under gravity to form protoplanets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after a planet reaches a diameter larger than the earth's moon it begins to accumulate an extended atmosphere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this serves to increase the capture rate of the planetesimals by a factor of ten
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the protostar has grown such that it ignites to form a star its solar wind blows away most of the disc's remaining material
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thereafter there still may be many protoplanets orbiting the star or each other but over time many will collide either to form a single larger planet or release material for other larger protoplanets or planets to absorb
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: those objects that have become massive enough will capture most matter in their orbital neighbourhoods to become planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: meanwhile protoplanets that have avoided collisions may become natural satellites of planets through a process of gravitational capture or remain in belts of other objects to become either dwarf planets or small solar system bodies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the energetic impacts of the smaller planetesimals will heat up the growing planet causing it to at least partially melt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the interior of the planet begins to differentiate by mass developing a denser core
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: smaller terrestrial planets lose most of their atmospheres due to this accretion but the lost gases can be replaced by outgassing from the mantle and from the subsequent impact of comets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that smaller planets will lose any atmosphere they gain through various escape mechanisms with the discovery and observation of planetary systems around stars other than our own it is becoming possible to elaborate revise or even replace this account
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the level of metallicity is now believed to determine the likelihood that a star will have planets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hence it is thought less likely that a metal poor population ii star will possess a substantial planetary system than a metal rich population i star
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to the iau definition there are eight planets in our solar system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in increasing distance from the sun they are with the astronomical symbol in brackets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all planets revolve around the sun in the same direction counter clockwise as seen from over the sun's north pole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the period of one revoultion of a planet's orbit is known as its year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a planet's year depends on its distance from the sun the farther a planet is from the sun not only the longer the distance it must travel but also the slower its speed as it is less affected by the sun's gravity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all planets also rotate around invisible axes at their centres
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the period of one rotation of a planet is known as its day
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most planets including the earth rotate as they revolve in a counter clockwise direction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: venus alone among the planets rotates clockwise
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if it were possible to see the sun from the surface of venus it would rise in the west and set in the east
